Landed here cruising around the union square while on a business trip. 
Extremely expensive for the portion sizes they offer. There is nothing special about the dishes they claim to be. 

I would rate it pricey for the average quality of food they offer and claim it to be inspired by royalty back in India. Save your money for a lot of excellent indian food places around.
author: Chetan K.

description:
This place was totally awful! We visited about 10 Indian restaurants on our recent visit to SF and this place was the worst of the lot! Why? 

1. The service was obnoxiously rude and the staff licked the boots of white people and looked down upon the other Indian patrons. They are the reason that British colonialism existed in India. 

2. The food was terrible - nothing is cooked fresh and everything is just microwaved -- when our Kofta was frozen cold to the core they said that we were very stupid people to think so. 

3. They gave us chutneys and pickle and lemon and everything else without asking for it -- and then they charged us for each thing! That's called cheating right? 

I warn everyone about this place!
author: Shradha A.

description:
Keep walking this place is pretty bland and pricey. Make sure you look at your bill twice!!!! We were a table of 4 and the manager decided to tack on the Service Charge because he felt like. This was something that the waiter mentioned when we asked why we were being charged. Mind you we eat out alot and i used to be a waitress, so i always tip 18 to 20 percent. The fact that the manager just felt like adding it on to out bill was just unbelievable, did he think we were going to skip out?? WTH! 

Anyways... like a mentioned the food was bland and not worth the price. You should go else where.... 
And if you decided to go, read the fine print.. the management has the right to charge you a service charge for whatever number of people are at your table.

Never eating there again!!!!
author: Gladys P.

description:
It was a Friday night... we were staying at the Westin St. Francis in Union Square, we were already one strong ass drink  (from Lefty's) in to our night and our quest to find a place to grab some dinner was back on.

We were in the mood for some Indian and knew our choices in the vicinity were Naan & Curry, Sultan and New Delhi, but of course being the lushes that we are we ended up at New Delhi because duhhh there's a bar where we could drink while we waited for our table.

Upon arrival we were informed by the hostess and bartender that there were two large parties so it would be a while until we could be seated. We hadn't waited any more than 10 minutes before we were escorted to a table. Walking through the dinning room my dinner companion and I were both struck by the complete lack and absence of ethnic patrons. Seriously the presence of white folk around us disturbed us both. Why wasn't there a more ethnically diverse group of people in this restaurant?  We were afraid the demographic might be reflective of the quality of food, but we were too buzzed and too hungry to jump ship.

I liked how the menu included some historical background on the dishes. We ordered the lamb biryani our staple Indian restaurant dish and the tamarind eggplant. I wasn't wowed by the food but it got the job done. I've had better lamb biryani but this rendition got the job done. The tamarind eggplant was sweet and spicy. I had never ordered this dish before but I look forward to looking for it on other restaurant menus.

With so many other great places to dine in SF, I wouldn't race back here, but I would keep it in mind.
author: Lori K.

description: What a poor imitation of a curry. Tomato paste and some curry powder, served up - in tiny portions - as an assortment of dishes. Bland and average - I've had better Indian in a food court. Nice place though. But if you're looking for some exotic flavours, sadly this is not the place to find it. Disappointing.
author: Robin R.

description:
DRINk:
Only came here to drink. (They unfortunately do not carry root beer, haha)


SERVICE:
Love the bartenders here! Honestly friendly. Say hi to Scottie & Esmerelda ;P


ATMOSPHERE:
It's nice, I only go here for the bar which is in the front. Not too big, it leads to the rest of the restaurant. Not too big either, good handful of tables, nicer end, with linen tablecloths
author: Angela L.

description:
We came here on New Years Eve, having a nearby engagement for the night and looking for a good place to eat beforehand. Although not wowed, we thought that New Delhi Indian Restaurant was good.

For our meal here, we ordered the complete dinner (non-vegetarian), rice and Keema nan. We were hoping this would be enough food for two people, after the waiter made it seem like the complete dinner was really more of a one person thing, but it ended up being more than enough to fill us both up. There is a good amount of food with just the complete dinner, and to our surprise it came with rice too so we had a huge surplus of grainy goodness.

In terms of the positives, the rice was excellent, some of the better we have had. The mint chutney was also superb, as was the tea. On the downside, the Keema nan was a little dry, with the lamb not being anywhere near as flavorful as it should be. Everything else was so-so, from the decent chicken masala to the veg dish. The service was polite and attentive, though, to end on a good note.

Overall, New Delhi Indian Restaurant was okay. Its probably a "high 3", but not quite the 4 level for us and we probably won't be back.
author: Sami R.

description:
Enjoyed the Chicken Curry, Eggplant, and Garlic Naan and Rice.

Well I've had really really good chicken curry before and this one was sorta different, It wasn't really a spicy dish, maybe they assumed I wouldn't like it spicy.

Overpriced for what was offered like the other reviewers have said.

The samosas were pretty good though, along with the garlic naan, I think i was just a little let down by the curry and its relative blandness.

Checking out Little Dehli next instead.
author: Steven H.

description: Totally disappointed! I travel to San Francisco about 3 times a year and every time I go I always go to New Delhi. I walked in at 1:35pm and the employee ( who I think was the owner ) told me they were closing in 5 min, so therefor I was too late. When I asked if there was another restaurant they could recommend the guy gave me a rude look and said no! The food is good, but they treat the customer like shit!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
My partner and I were staying quite literally right above the New Delhi Restaurant at the Hotel Nikko, so it's location was super convenient.  I love Indian food, but I am very critical of whether or not it is of good quality, so I was very interested to see how New Delhi could do.  

From the moment we arrived, the service was impeccable.  We were seated immediately and our waitress was incredibly attentive without being annoying.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and deceivingly large on the inside-- it looks like a hole in the wall from the outside.

Now to the food... AMAZING.  My partner and I started off with mango lasses to drink, and then ordered naan, garlic naan (for me), raita, saffron rice, chana masala and the chicken korma for dinner.  All of it was spectacular EXCEPT (and this is why it is not a five star review) for the chicken in the chicken korma.  While I am used to leg or thigh meat being used in these recipes, it seemed like every piece that either I or my partner bit into still had some cartilage or semi-hard fat attached to it.  I am really squeamish about that consistency in my mouth, so it was a little tenuous at points.  However, the sauce the chicken was cooked in more than made up for that.  I could have eaten a vat of that with their sublime naan.

The star of dinner was their homemade raita.  We wound up ordering two orders of it.  Our waitress informed us that it is completely made from scratch in the kitchen-- including the yogurt used.  Honestly, it was the freshest most flavorful raita I have ever eaten.

I highly recommend that if you are ever in the city to find this place and stuff yourself to the brink of unconsciousness.  We spent right around $50 for two people and I know it will be a meal that I will remember for a long time.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Randomly stumbled upon this place while walking out from Parc 55 Wyndam... starving. My friends and I had just flown in and decided to grab lunch. Great, friendly service..   Food came out very quickly (but then again, it was an early lunch in the middle of the week - not many people were there). We had the Chicken Tikka Masala, Fish Masala, and the Matar Paneer. All very good, but nothing SPECTACULAR. However, the naan came out nice and hot - literally fresh out of the oven. Mmm...

Stop by four a quick meal, or drink (they have a bar, score!), if you're in the area. Can't go wrong with good food, drinks, and great service.
author: Sandra J.

description: The food was fine, but the portions were small and overpriced.  We only stopped here because it was right across from my hotel. The best thing I had here was the garlic naan, but the chicken masala and chicken tandoori were both minuscule. We also found the service to be quite slow.
author: Kelly M.

description:
Great atmosphere, very delicious food. I'm a big fan of Indian food so it's always a treat to try a new place. The four of us family styled four entrees and they were all solidly very good. A lot of old standards but also many items that were fairly unique, at least to me. Rice and naan are ordered separately so we got two naan and two rice to round out the meal. The portions seemed a tad small for the price, but maybe leaving a table not stuffed to the gills is a good thing.  Next time, and there will be one, maybe we'll get an appetizer too, since they had a good looking selection of those as well. 
I wish I could remember specifically what we had. There was a mango prawn dish that made me wish for extra naan for dipping, a keema mattar, well seasoned and tasty, a specialty of the house w chicken, cashews & grated paneer which was unique and delicious, but can't recall the fourth.  We left with happy bellies. Oh and the service was very attentive and friendly.  Lots of space, seems like larger parties would be welcome.
author: Dar V.

description:
Another Desi Restaurant which believes that if you bill yourself as a fine dining restaurant you don't need to be authentic.

Food was mostly OK, but not as spicy as we had asked it to be. The Garlic Naan was without garlic and the sweet Lassi was too sour. However what really turned us off was that the men's restroom smelled of pee.

Recommendation for Desis: There are better desi restaurants out there.
author: Desi D.

description: Where to begin.... Place is feast for the eyes, and that is about it.  Service was cold but efficient.  Menu is typical, nothing that will wow you, and the food, I am guessing some low budget frozen food that they get from Restaurant Depot, because that is what it taste like.  If you want to eat in a pretty restaurant with good drinks, but meh food, eat here.
author: sean d.

description:
Talk about FIVE star Indian food!!! 

The hospitality was second to none...they were very attentive of our table.

The selection of food was definitely excellent as well as the selection of drinks.

Very warm and comfortable dining area, tables were spacious as well as the seating next to the surrounding tables.  

Portion sizes were well proportioned for the number of folks in my party.  

The food, OMG, was soooo good. I could taste the spices from the northern Indian dish I had, which is rare.  Sometimes species get lost but New Delhi did a great job of bringing out the uniqueness of flavors within their dishes.  Also the food was very fresh.

The next time I am in SF and in the mood for Indian food, I will definitely be coming back!
author: E Katrina L.

description:
I have no idea how this place is able to remain in business. We were visiting from LA and It was our first trip to SF. My wife and I are die hard Indian food fans. We have visited over a dozen Indian restaurants so we have pretty much acquired a good taste for quality Indian food. We initially noticed the nice decor and visibly this restaurant has in Union Square. Being die heart Indian food fans, we had to try it. I wish I had read some of the reviews first!

We walked in on black Friday after Thanksgiving and noticed that the place was actually quite empty. We asked the manager for a table and was asked if we had a reservation. Of course we didn't so we were asked to wait 15 minutes while the place was nearly empty. We were seated and greeted by the waiter who was not really friendly. All the while I was thinking maybe this is the typical attitude of waiters in SF... so after a couple questions, we ordered some chicken tikka masala, garlic naan and a couple of other dishes.

I still gave them the benefit of the doubt at this point since the food hadn't been served yet thinking maybe they have such great tasting food and they can afford to lack in customer service... boy was I wrong!

The first thing we noticed were the portions, I mean c'mon! I know they say serving small portions leaves a better taste in ones mouth but this was ridiculous. The next thing I noticed was the white rice we ordered. It looked and tasted like it was 3 days old reheated in a microwave with stale grains all over the place. Again, IT'S RICE! it almost has no cost to restaurant so why not serve it fresh? Next came the Naan.. again no surprise here, it was almost cold with no garlic taste at all. we didn't understand how they could serve such food to customers. Of course the real kicker was the bill... WAY OVERPRICED!

Before people think we are one of those people who look to find something to complain about think again. Dining out for 15 years, I can only count 2 or 3 restaurants that have been almost this bad. This place gets the crown for being the worst. When we go to a restaurant, we don't really care about the customer service because we understand that we may have come in at a very busy time or short staffed etc. We don't care about the decor because we believe restaurant owners and chefs who are there because they love what they do might not have the money to spend on eye candy. We don't look at the price too much either because we believe price should reflect quality. But there is absolutely no excuse for having bad food, NONE! 

This place really does a disservice to SF and its visitors. We came out judging SF food by this place which is a shame. We will never visit this place again and hope others don't either.
author: Nick M.

description:
Geat new hang out.  The bar rocks, the bartender rocks, and the apps were very good.  Had the nam bread with spicy lamb and one with grilled onions and garlic.

The bartender was super nice and made some great recomendations!  You will find me here alot!
author: Kenneth G.

description:
The restaurant bills itself as indian food learnt from the kitchens of Indian Maharajahs..well Indian Maharajahs used to keep a person employed to taste food before they ate it. The New Delhi restaurant would  do well to have someone taste their food as well before they dish it out to customers.
we ordered the chicken, which was really bad. The koftas were ok, and the bread was average..we had to ask to get our water filled.
The mango lassi was great....
author: Bhaskar C.

description: I've been here a couple of times while visiting San Francisco. The food is good enough to rate this place 5 stars. Naan, Tiki Masala, Chicken Korma... all are excellent.  Service is what's lacking... our drinks were constantly empty and the service wasn't especially friendly. Price-for-portion size wasn't terrific either.  Still, the deliciousness of the food itself is worth at least four stars.
author: Brad B.

description: Ordered lemonade and pappadums as appetizer.  Lemonade was ok but papad was oily and the center was not fried. Ordered veg dinner for myself.  Was served samosa and pakora appetizer.  The appetizer did not taste fresh and was over-fried.  The main dinner had two curries, dal, naan and rice. The dal lacked flavor and the curries seemed overcooked.  Naan and rice were good. Dessert was rice kheer in which rice tasted stale and there were no nuts or cardamom flavor.  The food was not worth $22.  The only saving grace was chai that came as part of the dinner.  Service was fine.  Expected better value for money on food.
author: Vinima A.

description: walkable from our hotel,m Hilton Union Square..elegant old hotel, with columns and pleasant setting...tablclothes and good service. I had chicken tandori, nan bread and raita...served hot and well. My husband had another dish, cant remember the name, and I  had delicious rice pudding. we also  had a 1/2 price off second meal coupon...nice bar and we could hear ourselves talk.
author: Adriana O.

description:
We showed up with 8 people and no reservation on a Friday night at 8pm and were seated within 5 minutes. Sadly, however, that's the best the service got. It took a long time for anyone to take our drink orders, and there were long stretches of time without anybody coming by. 

The food was pretty standard for Indian. I think those at the table who enjoy their food fire-hot may have been a little disappointed - I'm unadventurous like that, so I was perfectly happy with my dish. You can order your food in "grades" of spiciness, which is helpful! It was a little frustrating that, for the price of the entrees, they did not include rice or naan. We ended up needing to order 4 orders of naan and 3 orders of rice for the whole table of 8. It would have been helpful if the menu had at least specified what was and was not included with the entree price (although they might lose business when people realized they are paying $15 for a small metal bowl of meat in sauce). Portions were also on the small side for price - after 15 minutes there was not a single bite left on the table (although we were pretty ravenous by that point). 

I'm not sure what the other options for Indian are in the area, and this wasn't a bad experience - it just wasn't great. If you want something special, I'd go elsewhere. But for a pretty standard Indian meal - if a little pricey for what you get - New Delhi was decent.
author: Laura S.

description:
Went with a group of friends from out of town and had a wide selection from vegetarian and non vegetarian menus. Portions are definitely small and food was good but not as amazing as their advertising suggests and  was not as hot when it arrived on the table. I'd give the food a 3. 

Unfortunately service was very underwhelming. It was a Sunday evening and there was just 1 waitress available. Food came out very slow. 2 stars.

Decor was ok, but again not as amazing as the website would have you believe. 2.5 Stars.

All in all a sub par experience which is disappointing given the website claiming this to be THE place to go for a quality experience.
author: R D.

description:
I only ate here on accident, mistaking it for my dear Little Delhi (which I've only ever ordered delivery) after being away for a month.

The food was quite bland. The garlic naan didn't taste like garlic at all, to the point where I thought I'd been brought the wrong thing. Nope. Chicken in the chicken tikka masala was a bit gristly and had a lot of dark meat, which I'm not really a fan of.

Service was fine, waitress was friendly and attentive, but there were only two tables at the time, including myself.

They serve everything on fancy plates and the decor is probably supposed to be impressive, but it just feels dated and empty. Someone kept dimming the lights, and considering it was about 2pm, it was kinda weird.
author: Dani A. C.

description:
Bad ambiance - the pictures of naked women on the wall are not even artsy! Just vulgar. And I am no prude!

Food was pedestrian. Nothing exceptional. Standard fare, but expensive.

The icing on the cake was the fire alarm that went off during our meal. Not their fault, but they did not evacuate (just a drill), but did not turn it off either for half an hour! Expensive dinner with wife ruined.
author: Xander C.

description:
Avoid this tourist Indian food trap.  Dishes all tasted the same. No spices. So many rules about what you are allowed to order. The plain naan had more flavour than anything else. 

Service was efficient but unhelpful. People next to us were told coupon would not be honored. Even when they complained, they were told that it was their mistake. Horrible having to listen to waiter argue with them. Could have been handled much better

Everything here is extra charge. Couple at another table had to ask more than once for hot sauce.   

Our order was not fully delivered.

Just keep walking   

I've had boxed Indian food that had more spices.
author: Karen L.

description:
Somewhat on the expensive side for mediocre food. I had lunch a 14.95 for Chicken Korma and a 3.95 Basmati Rice. The rice was lump and could have been cooked yesterday, while in the case of the curry it was an exercise in finding where the meat was in a thick sauce that was loaded with nuts instead. 

Definitely a case of look elsewhere!
author: Sid C.

description: Good food.  We had the Chicken Masala.  I thought it was flavored well and was delicious.  We also had the Tandori shrimp.  I felt these were overcooked and dry, as such the flavor was cooked out of them.  Garlic naan was great.  Also had rice and samosas which were great. I would go back and plan to the next time I am in Frisco
author: Tim F.

description: The worst Indian food I have ever had in my entire life. If I can summarize our experience at this place recently...it's a barely a one star place with very expensive tasteless food with lousy service. The only reason we went to this place was their great website...the one star rating is just for that. For starters, we ordered Tandoori mixed grill and paneer pakoras. It is customary to serve a tandoori dish on a "smoking" cast iron plate...instead, the item was served on a plate with "un grilled onions and bell peppers"...the praws were overcooked and the chicken tika and seeg kababs were cold. The paneer pakoras tasted stale. For the main course, we ordered Lamb bhoona, fish masala, tadka daal and eggplant bharta with some rotis. The lamb bhoona was tasteless...just a bunch of boiled lamb pieces sautéed in generic brown onion gravy. I am not sure what the fish was...pieces of fish mixed with tasteless light colored gravy. The tadka daal had neither the color nor the taste. The eggplant dish was similar with uncooked green peas. Total bill for this was over $100. My advise to Mr Ranjan Dey is to spend some serious time in the kitchen so that the food they serve represents the hype of your web site.
author: S P.

description: what a fantastic restaurant. really one of my all time favorites. They have some wonderful chef creations that you will not find any were else. They have a bar up front which is a nice waiting area you can take a seat at. The restaurant itself is beautiful done with great authenticate artwork and paintings. the food is to die for! i have even heard that ex-president Clinton dines there when he is in the city. i don't know if that's true but its quite a recommendation if it is true. All in all a must go resturant.
author: Sarmad N.

description: Food here was decent. Wanted BBQ but was told I would have to wait another 30 minutes. Service was a little sketchy. No one welcomed us, required a single ticket per table, who does that? That's just laziness.
author: Thom A.

description:
I been to New Delhi restaurant on Friday night, initially I was happy to see the restaurant but when they served food, It was "HORRIBLE". It seems, they cooked in the morning for evening and it was not at all hot. I called the server and he said, Sorry but didn't make any action to warm it again. And the quantity is very less compare to price.

I won't go there again. I think, this is worst restaurant for vegetarian people and  they don't pay any attention  if you don't ask for wine.

In case, if owner read the review then he should learn for how to take care to cust,
instead of just giving check after the complain.


-Somdev
author: SS S.

description:
Me and a friend were really excited to have Indian food on our trip in SF. So we randomly picked this spot as it was near our hotel... well, it sucked.

The food was pretty blend, the prices were high. The spice was almost non-existence. It was a huge tourist trap and we fell right in it. If you've never had India food before, this is a place for you cause it's catered to people who can't handle spicy food. I ordered a Vindaloo and that didn't made me cry like I used to in other Indian places. It was so blah.
We had garlic naan and it was freaking garlic powder. Really? Garlic Powder? And you're charging how much?
Also, is it so hard to refill my cup with water when there's only 2 other groups in the restaurant?

Bad food, bad service, good decor, hefty on the wallet.
author: Leon C.

description:
KHANA and PINNA!!!

(pubjabi for EAT and DRINK!!!)

For the drinking part of that quote their mango lassis could easily become a substitute for water in my daily intake of fluids. You honestly cannot get enough of that drink and for those who want an alcoholic flair to their meal the New Delhi Sunset is tasty mctasty!!! And their description of their Delhi Wala on their menu is "Lemon drop with an indian attitude" which perfectly sums up this fabulous indian restaurant. 

Food wise where do I start!! Their samosas are not overcoked and not too greasy and you can't believe how fast they disappear from your appetizer plate. Their saag is some of the best I have ever had and their chicken and lamb dishes are SOOOOOOO tender making it extra easy to take on this meal with your hands which is how real indian dining happens. For $27 you can get a whole indian feast brought to your table with tandoori chicken which actually has spice!!! (imagine that, a spicy indian dish with actual spice in it!! I didn't really need any chutney for that dish!) and seekh kabobs. And their naan is actually less than $2!!! It always angers me when indian places try charging $3 and $4 for one naan when it is really just bread and your utensil for eating!!! 

So props to them for their fresh well priced naan and all the rest of the fixings!!!!
author: Sarah G.

description: First stepping into the interior lets you know this is classy.  The food was delicious.  I enjoyed the black lentils, chana masala, and garlic naan.  The chana masala was spicy, and I liked that.  The garlic naan was fragrant.  The bland rice did not really appeal to me.  I would give it 4 stars but dinner for four with tip was $120.  Sorry, there's other Indian restaurants in the city with less ambiance yet better value food.
author: Ethan K.

description:
My friend had been longing to try this place having received a glowing recommendation from another friend.  So, for her birthday off we went to try it out.  Now having grown up in a Pakistani household I'm a bit of a snob when it comes to Pakistani cuisine.  The food wasn't the worst I have eaten but it certainly wasn't the best, it was definitely catering to a Western palate and not that spicy.

What was most disappointing was the service, it wasn't too bad to begin with - it wasn't a busy night and half the restaurant was empty.  We were shown to our table, service was prompt and then we noticed it was a little too prompt, just as we received our food, the waiter came by to see how things were and then came by again and again.  As soon as we'd finished our eaten and while we were still chatting our bill was brought to our table, we paid and continued chit chatting, after about 10 minutes an older gentleman came over and asked us to move to the bar... I was shocked to say the least, as I mentioned it wasn't busy and half the restaurant was empty.  Needless to say I won't be back!
author: Shamaila A.

description: Fish was low grade in the fish masala, but had good flavor.  I'd go with chicken or lamb if I came again.
author: Josh L.

description: Good, but too expensive.
author: Michael E.

description:
Ragan is one of the most kind chefs ever.  He does so much for the Tenderloin community and never shies away from an opportunity to help out a charity.  
But I wouldn't eat here unless the food was great.  I've never had a dish I didn't enjoy from the curries to tandoories, naans and biriyanis.  The dining room is also impressively decadent looking.
author: Monica L.

description: The food is delicious! Adding to this experience is the customer service. Truly above and beyond. New Delhi reminds me of good restaurants in Europe. Relaxed, and attentive with a superb menu.
author: April-Monét R.

description:
I have to come from Alameda to the city for several Mondays in a row to see my dentist for various procedures. I try to eat lunch there before returning to the  island. Although I tend to be a creature of habit, today while planning to return to a sushi boat place on Geary, I stumbled across this place.

Being by myself, I wasn't able to order a representative variety of food. But nevertheless I enjoyed my meal. I had a lamb vindaloo, raita, onion kulcha (naan), Indian pickles, and a nice large Taj Mahal.

The decor/ambiance was quite nice, neo-classical Indian with large columns. The service was ok to nice. The main waiter was pleasant, friendly, not very engaging at first, more so toward the end. Another person there who may have been an owner or manager went around to ask how everything was.

There were two women who had a little complaint. I couldn't really hear all the conversation, but my interpretation was that the rice arrived late, too late for them to even eat it with their meal. (They may have assumed that rice comes automatically with the meal which it doesn't  and is not unusual for an Indian restaurant.) The owner/manager came around to inquire about the meal and he encouraged them to tell him about any issues. They reluctantly told him. He profusely thanked them. I think he took off the charge for the rice. That's only from my interpretation of the body language and visual queues.

The food was very nice. My only issue was that my vindaloo which I ordered "very, very, very spicy" was medium. The waiter did write "hot" on the order, but I guess the cook didn't understand English.

Overall I enjoyed my meal!
author: Nobbi L.

description:
Great food, lousy prices!

$17 for Chicken Tikka Masala? No thanks!

Portions are no different than any other regular Indian restaurant, yet New Delhi deems itself worthy enough to charge 2x as much! 

Next time, I am going to Little Delhi instead.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
My fellow Indians, AVOID THIS PLACE LIKE THE PLAGUE, save your money and make the food at home, this place is a real shit-hole.

To set the scene:
My wife and I had been out all day hiking and we wanted to have some good old fashioned Indian food and I had heard about this place so we tried it..., mistake #1.


We walked in and the entrance looked like a sports bar....., URRR OK, then we walked in a little further and we see a large space and spaciously laid out tables, with minimal customers on a SATURDAY NIGHT, why did'nt I see the warning signs the? Mistake #2.

We sat down and our waitress who seemed nice (mistake #3)  took our order and our starters were OK, I ordered a beer and the scruffy, overweight wait staff took forever to get it for me, it took hand signals to gt their attention and finally get some Indian beer down me!!!

We ordered our mains which all looked the same, all cooked with the same sauce (which looked like yogurt and cream) where's the onions, the garlic, the herbs and spices???
We requested a change in the order and our waitress was not best pleased, I'm sorry, but aren't I the customer...? I was very pleasant yet clear about what we wanted, until she started getting a little short and rude with my wife which is when I put my foot down and said I want to change the order and have a new plate of food.

The waiters spoke little or no English and god only knows why there were people eating in this place as it is NOT desi Indian food, that I can promise you.

I am North Indian and from England, the capital of Indian restaurant food and Indian takeouts. This place would close down within a week if it was in the UK...

If you're a local, you should know better, tourists AVOID!!!!

Enough said

Fellow desi
author: King O.

description:
Decent...

Ordered the FULL tandoori platter, which is supposed to come with fish, shrimp, chicken, sheesh kebab, and something else...for $19.99, I expected a mountain of grilled deliciousness, only to be disappointed with a piece of fish maybe a quarter of the size of a playing card, 2 pieces of shrimp, 2 pieces of chicken (ok), and whatever the meat I cannot remember was...bottom line is I wouldn't have paid $9.99 had I known it came with so little food, let alone $19.99!

The Naan was decent...ordered normal and garlic...was a little on the thick side for my liking. 

For my main dishes I order the "spicy" tamarind chicken...I asked for it EXTRA spicy, as spicy as possible...what a joke...I didn't get any extra spice as far as I could tell...let alone what I was looking for.

The chicken tikka masala (not on menu, but recommended) was very pleasent, perhaps just a bit too creamy, but I didn't mind that

The rice with pineapple, clove, etc was decent, but I wouldn't order again...would have prefered just basmati rice with my dishes

Service was ok...biggest disappointment was that I got really excited when I saw on the menu "see a demo of the tandoor over, just ask manager and if we're not too busy, we'll show you"....there were only a handful of people at best in the restaurant, yet I was refused and the waiter sort of eluded that yes they state that on the menu, but they don't really do it... bummer :(

The dishes were small, but tasty...not the best I've had for sure...and rather expensive (my bill for this was $84!)...and yes, I am 1 person and I ate it all...I do eat a lot, but even for me to have eaten this many dishes, the portions had to have been small

HTH
author: Tommy C.

description:
The food here is pretty good, but the portions are painfully small. I ordered 4 entrees, rice, and naan for 1 girl and 3 boys and I felt kind of bad when the food came out. It ended up being a game of "No no, you have the last piece" tag. It was still delicious, especially the paneer tikka masala, but I just wish I got more for my money.

The real reason you should come to this restaurant is the drinks. Holy moly, are they strong! I recommend the Mango Madness which is basically rum, rum, and thick mango juice. It's probably the tastiest cocktail I've ever had. I also recommend their Tokyo Iced Tea which is essentially pure alcohol and is only $6!! I only need one and I get pretty loopy. Don't laugh.
author: Joyce Man H.

description: Went there for dinner. Great vegetarian options. Got the vegetarian tika masla. Delicious. Food came out super fast and was delicious!! Would definitely come back.
author: Nurit Z.

description: Definitely not recommend this place. Overpriced their foods with no reasons. Foods are definitely not worth that price. I have never see that small among of fried rice cause $20 dollars a dish. Definitely a scam place. High price low quality of food. Never eat there again
author: Liana L.

description:
The decor wasn't bad. Ambiance was nice. Price was steep. Food was okay but the service was HORRIBLE!! 

The samosas were really good! They were the best part of my entire meal. The price was a little steep for samosas but they were worth it. 

The main course was just okay-if that. Garlic naan didn't have fresh garlic so ur better off just ordering plain naan. I was hoping they'd have butter chicken but they didn't so I had to settle for the similar chicken tika masala. It's was pretty good but the quantity is just enough for one person. Actually everything was basically for a personal size which was disappointing bc we were under the impression that they were meant to be shared. And for the amount you get, you sure are paying a lot. Tandoori chicken was good and juicy but almost not even worth getting bc we had to wait close to an hour to get served. They said it was bc the tandoori chicken takes a long time to make. No one ever bothered to check up on us after the samosas were served. We had to ask them as they passed by. And when we asked our waitress for the second time she went to the back and never came back to talk to us. Talk about rude! We almost walked out of there. So the daal was okay... Nothing special but it was a little on the cold side. Hariyali chicken was too sour. 

Like I said the service was horrible. We were starving by the time we got our food. They don't seem to care about service very much. They only refilled the small water glasses once and never came back. Overall just a frustrating experience. I would never go back.. But if u really want to try it out just go for the samosas (the only reason im giving them two stars) that's simple enough for them to handle, I think.
author: Amrita M.

description: Great ambience - the place has real character - but the food was a bit of a let down. The sauces were a little bland. Perhaps they should offer fewer dishes and do them better?
author: Alex B.

description:
My biggest complaints for this place are prices and portion size. The food was great but because there was so little of it at a high price, I felt disappointed.

We ordered one starter, three entrees, three lassis, two glasses of milk and another non-alcoholic drink and it came to $91.08 (incl. tax, excl. tip).

The entrees were tiny.

The quality of the food, service and ambiance were great though.
author: Adrian B.

description: I understand it closes at 10p.m we got there at 9:20 and were told dinner is closed.. That is all we were told. I wont ever be coming back.
author: Chalonize S.

description: I just had the Kashmiri Pulao, which includes fragrant rice mixed with fruits. A great "meal" after my IPA. :-)
author: Steve F.

description: We had a wonderful time working with Ranjan Dey and his team at new Delhi restaurant, who catered our Sangeet. Ranjan prepared a fabulous tasting for us in his restaurant, and then worked with us over the next few months to establish a delicious and reasonably priced menu for our 200 plus guests. The food was plentiful and universally admired by our guests, and everything went off without a hitch. Ranjan was communicative and accommodating throughout the process, and the quality of his food and standard of service impeccable.
author: Emma A.

description:
Reliably delicious and friendly service. We always get the Lamb Vindaloo and a different dish to try, along with rice, naan, and papadums to start with.

The lamb has been tender every time and so good it's hard to stop stuffing my mouth even though it's on fire. Most recently I tried the Lemon Mustard Fish Curry, which was so tasty. The sauce on its own is a bit sour but goes perfectly with the fish.

Will be back here soon!
author: Kim V.

description:
I *loved* the food here.

Onion naan was excellent.

Basmati rice (served in a sort of pilaf style)... excellent.

Tandoori paneer... excellent (although, the samosa chaat was weird).

Lamb roganjosh... excellent.

Chicken tikka masala... ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. It wasn't your typical Chicken tikka. It was brown, and tasted quite different, with cashews. They also call it something else. So if it's not called chicken tikka, and it doesn't taste like chicken tikka, where did I get chicken tikka from?

Someone told me it was their modified version.

Also, I got this carbonated drink that had lemon, and lime, and rosewater. Very good.

But everything came in small portions.

All in all, check it out!
author: Jason G.

description: Stopped here after dinner for drinks.  The dark wood and full bar were comforting and the Steve the bar tender was totally cool.  The smells from the kitchen were fantastic and what surprised me were the number of Indian and Pakistanis eating there...always a good sign!  Drinks were good and quick.  We'll definitely be back for food!
author: David M.

description:
May 31, 2011: we were 6 people; new in town, we all veggie. Lets get to the point. First of all: there is a Guy who to took the order was REALLY RUDE... he told us we will have ORDER $18 or more per person no less then that, THEN ONLY HE takes our order and It wasn't said anywhere such pricing...
Another Negative Point: the quality of the food is really low, ONLY ONE person can able to eat.  So if you are going in groups like we did, we would have to order 6 dishes EVERY expensive. 
Positive is the food is Good and Lassi and bread are really nice..
author: Mihir M.

description: I went there because i wanted fine indian cousine. Myself also know to cook Indian food. But this place highly disappointed me. Never ever go there. Food was blunt, tasteless and costly.
author: Mike A.

description: Good ambience but food was just about OK. Spice levels were very low,and some were just tasteless. Chicken biryani was more like a tasteless pulav. Other items weremore like home food & not having a professional touch. Service was quick!
author: Ratish K.

description:
The food was just awful. This is not an authentic Indian restaurant, and def. not the best in the nation (that's what it says on their website). 

To those of you that are not Indian, read the reviews written by the Indian folks. You will notice that most of us gave this place a 1 star. Why? B/c  we know what good authentic Indian food tastes like, and this was def. not one of them. So do take our advice and don't go here. 

The place was pretty, I'll give it that, but do yourself a favor and get your moneys worth elsewhere.
author: Rin R.

description:
i am Indian , love exploring other cuisines but always revert back to Indian food. I work downtown so i'm always hitting the restaurants around there. 
New Delhi is definitely not worth the price. I like their bar and stop over after work once a while for a  quiet beer. Friendly bartenders, and i also like the staff. But the food has been uniformly bad or mediocre...
I don't mind paying well for good food, but as other reviewers have suggested, there is a huge disparity between the quality of food and the price.
Their signature dishes are so bogus, i can't really tell what they're trying to do. All those references to royal palates and history, and they come up with nonsense.
 Some of it's straight of the freezer, sometimes they don't bother to defrost it properly (  i've had samosas that were cold inside; their koftas, tiny meatballs definitely were not made fresh- it doesn't take much to make meatballs...i think).

go to little delhi instead, definitely more satisfying, simpler fare, and reasonably well done. If you want good Indian/ pakistani food around a 3 block radius, go to Shalimar. Divey, but god, so good!
author: K K.

description: Went here for lunch. We were the only ones in the restaurant for the entire time we were there, a warning sign. The service was attentive and friendly. However the food was not excellent. It wasn't bad either. The chicken dish we had was disappointing though, it was as if they used cheap chicken stock. It was tough. Also thought it was odd they did not serve alcohol until the bar opened at 5:30. I would not go back.
author: Eric N.

description:
I didnt think this place was that great.  I think the decor is nice, but kind of off.  Corinthian columns?  I didnt get it.  The colors are very Indian I guess.

Now, for the food.  I agree with some of the reviewers here that the food was not proportionate to the price.  I think the only thing that tasted good from what we ordered--and we ordered a lot to share--was abad idea...which I will be getting to since it did not match up.  The curry comes in small portions! All the Tandoori's were tasty, but not as tasty as they were claiming.  

The plus is that the alcohol was decently priced, not cheap, but at least not expensive.  Do not come here in groups!  The waiting wasnt that bad, although they did make a mistake with one of the orders.

Overall. It was whatever.  Dont make it a point to go fancy here.
author: Mark L.

description:
Boy was the food terrible -- tasted very bland, and I was deeply disappointed by the portion sizes relative to the prices. I guess they cater mostly to the tourists at Union Square and nearby hotels, so repeat business isn't high on the agenda.  However the decor tries pretty hard to be royal Indian, so I give them some credit for that.

Do yourself a favor, spend a few more dollars, and go to Amber just about a block away for fresher ingredients, high quality and tasty food, and a very good happy hour.
author: Vikram K.

description:
I'm a bar eater and I love this resturants bartenders. I come here for the fruit infused alcohol, like lychee vodka and strawberry tequila. I come here for the bartenders who will make me a drink based on a fruit and my saying "go nuts." 

The food is also decent, but for me it is mostly an accent to the drinks I'm enjoying.
author: Vee B.

description:
The ambiance (it's a former hotel ballroom) impressed us.  Service was satisfactory.  However, I believe the food is supposed to be the star in any restaurant experience.  The prices are way, way too high for the quality and quantity of the servings.  We had an extremely skimpy veggie platter with two ordinary and not even close to spicy enough dipping sauces.  Our entrees were bland and 
extraordinarily ordinary, besides being microscopically small.  Naan was an extra cost, and we received the plain variety, rather than the garlic version that we ordered.  Not a satisfying experience.  Will never return.  If you go, prepare to be astonished by the price-to-serving-size disparity.  It is a jaw-dropping experience.
author: Steven O.

description:
Best Indian Food we have had in the States...

Chicken Vindaloo was AMAZING!!!!!
author: Chris B.

description: Awful service, wait staff who simply made us feel like our business was better taken elsewhere.. And that's what we will be doing. We know good food, and good restaurants, having traveled around the world and having eaten at many high end restaurants, this combination of awful tasting food + tiny portions + terrible service( we were literally asked to go, for staying 5 minutes past the 10 PM closing time) does not justify the  high end pricing.
author: Vidya V.

description: tasteless food. just the ambience but what will you do with that. you came here for food. If you want to have Indian food try nearby restaurant's.
author: Abhishek K.

description:
If you want atmosphere, then it's a great place - really feel upscale. The rooms feel rich and presentation is Top-Notch

We had the Chicken Tikki (sp?) and Lamb Curry - the Tikki is not always on the menu -

The sauces were creamy and substantial - not runny.  However, the spices were VERY MILD - almost dull, in spite of ordering medium to spicy dishes.

Portions were small (I feel like Woody Allen all of the sudden - How did you like the restaurant ?     ----- Terrible, the food was awful and the portions were small)

But, actually, at these prices,  stingy portions add to the overall unhappy experience.  Rice, naan, etc all extra --

And, why, on a Sunday Night, when the place is 2/3's empty they would group parties  together and force each to be so close as to interfere with conversation - I dunno !! 

It needs a lot of work in the food and service department - and  with all the dining competition in SF, that's bad  - the prices have to come down by a 25% 

Not horrible,  just not worth the money
author: dave r.

description:
Price-to-Food or should I say bang for your buck = very good, although garlic naan is always lacking garlic :)

On last visit I was sitting at the bar & came across what appeared to be a score sheet from SF Department of Public Health. The score is 67 out of 100. 

Usually it is alarming when score is in high 80s , don't know how this place is open with 67. 

The food is good, prices are reasonable, and location is very convenient , I sincerely hope owners take a little more care of the place, and then it is a definite 4 star establishment.
author: Sean S.

description:
Horrible !! 
Ordered the kaali daal ( black lentils) and chicken masala, onion kulcha and Keema kulcha.  

The dal was completely bland and lumpy. 
The chicken was some mystery meat with cartilage and a watery sauce. 
The kulcha's were thick flour y and dry !! 
Service was very mediocre. The waitress kept dissapearing and we had to keep flagging the busser or another waitress. She brought us the check and then proceeded to the hostess stand to chit chat with the bartender. You would think she would want to close out her table. 

The restaurant is shotgun style and you have to walk all the way past the bar to the back. 
Avoid at all costs.
author: Jay R.

description: This place was the worst. The garlic naan is suppose to be made with real garlic and they make it with garlic paste completely destroying the Indian heritage of making naan. The service is marginal. We would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Yogesh G.

description:
I really liked this place.  Not only was our food delicious, but the wait staff were awesome and the place itself was beautiful.  Considering the quality of the food and the service, i don't think this is expensive at all.  This is one of the best Indian places i've ever been to.  I loved the whole experience of dining here.  Here's my breakdown:

Food - very authentic tasting with a huge variety. The entrees are about $15 each and, when they arrive, look really small. But it's much larger than you think and very filling.  We shared the Bombay Saffron Bhuna Lamb (sweet, tender lamb, not oily or gamey) and the Chicken Madras (lotsa chicken, good heat).  The naan was very soft & tastes like they prepared it fresh (still really hot!) and made in the tandoor like it's supposed to.  I usually don't like basmati rice b/c it's too hard, but it was tastey here.  The Kashmiri Delight tastes great, very frizzy, good lime flavor, refreshing.  My Mango Lassi is freshly prepared and tastey, though I would like it colder (it was room temp).  The only thing I didn't like was my dessert, Gulab Jamun. It was wayyyy too sweet for my taste.  

Service - our waiter was very nice, knowledgable, and very accomondating.  The other servers were super nice too. Our water's always filled, never less than half the glass.  Only down side is that when I asked to see how naan is prepared (as suggested in their menu), i couldn't b/c the kitchen was too busy.  I would've love to see that.

Decor etc - the high ceilings made us feel really comfortable and not crowded, even tho there were a lot of tables. Usually at indian places, i feel so cramped in.  Not here.  The whole place looks very professional and clean.  The peacock copper dishes set on the tables were reallllllly pretty.  Sadly, we don't use them.  Our waiter collected it away.  I wonder what they're used for.
author: Hydie N.

description:
I was not a huge fan of Indian cuisine until I came here. I was introduced to Chef and Owner Ranjan Dey through a private event I was coordinating. I have to say I was extremely impressed from the start. 

When first entering the restaurant there is a full bar that has exotic signature drinks. Rose water tea and lemonade are two of my favorite non- alcoholic drinks here! It's like drinking expensive perfume, it is more than just the taste, the aroma from each drink is delish. 

Just past the bar is the host/ess station. The staff at New Delhi Restaurant are extremely helpful and kind, starting here. Once seated, the restaurant is decorated like a palace (just in San Francisco). 

The entire meal was excellent. Some may consider New Delhi expensive but for the quality it is so worth it. If you are a light weight on spicy foods, just ask your waiter/ess for suggestions of what would work best for your palate.

*** Make sure you try their signature deserts.  They are all AMAZING!
author: Sarah C.

description:
The first thing you'll notice is that the place looks very upscale and very nice.  They deserve quite a bit of credit for that.  

The service was very friendly.  I don't think I ever finished my water in my glass before a waiter or waitress came by to refil it.  They were helpful on speciffic things on the menu (for us it was how spicy/mild things were) and were very polite.  

The food is a bit pricy compared to a normal sit down resaurant.  Expect to pay at least $14 per meal.  I was a bit dissapointed with the portion size compared to the price.  The food was great, but there wasn't quit enough quanity for me for me to consider the price "fair."  I went with my friend and my friend's aunt and we had quite a bit of food.  My friend and his Aunt were originally going to go for the curries of the world tasting but it got pushed back to a later date and they couldn't go so the owner payed back their two tickets which amounted to $70.  The $70 just about covered the 3 of us put together but THEN the owner threw in $25 for the inconvienence.  Plus he came down personally 3 times to check in on us and ask how everything was.  He was a super friendly personal guy.  So from my side of everything, it was free and we had quite a feast.  

From this visit alone I can give Little Delhi no less than 5 stars.  If it were under normal circumstances, I might personally give it a 4 or 3 star just for the price/quantity ratio.  Plus I'm not much of a classy eater so it wasn't quite my thing.  

Recommended if you have the wallet for it or really really love good Indian food.  Service and atmosphere A+ though.
author: Mason P.

description:
So, my boyfriend is obsessed with Indian food.  I on the other hand had never even experienced Indian food until we meet.  Naturally over the course of dating we've taken each other to our favorite haunts and while I've enjoyed the Indian food I've tried I had not become a true fan until I experienced the food at the New Delhi Indian Restaurant while visiting the San Francisco area.  

The food: simply wonderful.  Such an amazing fusion of flavor and spice, I only wish I can find its twin out here in San Diego.  My boyfriend too was blown away by the quality of food and had stated that this was by far one of his favorite experiences at an Indian bistro. 

The only thing that was a bit off when we had dined here was the fact that it was very, very warm inside and I believe they were short on staff the day we were here.  However, while at times the wait between was a bit long, our waitress was still great with what she had to work with and the warmth in the atmosphere was definitely overlooked by great food, conversation and good times!

I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Ashley F.

description:
I have to wonder where people eat if they think this food warrants the prices. I find it fairly bland and SERIOUSLY expensive. Dinner for two people at one meal I had there, one of whom is vegetarian, was over $50, and that did not include alcohol (she had water, I had chai). Oh wait, I notice that most of the diners here are white people, not those of Indian descent. Bad sign if the natives don't eat the food. But I guess since it's located in Tourist Trap Central, I should not be surprised that the food is made for what I call the "honky palate". 

The service always seems to be slow, at best. Once they drop off your food - in very tiny dishes, so if you wish to share among several people, you need to order at least 3 entrees - it's hard to get their attention if you have a problem. And on the (last) visit of the three I've experienced, I had a major problem.

In order to keep the bill reasonable, I ordered a meat appetizer since my other two friends don't eat meat. I thought I was ordering a chicken tikka kebob. So you can imagine my surprise when I was given what was essentially chicken mcnuggets, Indian style. Yup, I got fried and breaded chicken bits for my "kebob". wtf? I've eaten Indian food in six different states, and no where have kebobs been interpreted to be fried chicken nuggets. I finally managed to flag a waiterperson, ask why I got a fried dish when the menu didn't mention it being fried, and sent it back. So all we had to eat between three people was 2 orders of samosas, a curried vegetable dish, some spinach dish that later gave my friends an upset stomach, rice, my chai, and two orders of naan. That small amount of unremarkable food somehow totalled $47!

Mind you, when the bill came, the chicken mcnuggets were still on there, which brought the original total to $56. The waitress said we didn't tell her we sent them back, to which I replied, "you never bothered to come back to the table once you brought the food, so I didn't even have an opportunity to order anything else before my friends finished their food". 

The only reason we went there this time around was because my friend had a gift certificate. The first time I dined there, my friend from Vancouver's sister, who lives in Vallejo, chose the place. I wanted to go to Naan and Curry, but she told him the food at ND was fabulous. It was not, but we sure did drop a good chunk of change, which would have been better spent on a quality meal elsewhere. I don't like spending $20+ per person, just to be hungry two hours later because the portions are so tiny, or you get fast food at sit-down prices. Honestly, I can't get over the chicken mcnuggets... Learn from my pain and avoid! You won't be missing anything at all, except a lighter wallet. Oh, and my Vancouver friend, who just returned from a year of living and travelling in India, never encountered chicken nuggets outside of Mc Donalds. So there you go.
author: LunaCat X.

description:
Joel's law of Asian/Indian food:  When you walk into an Indian restaurant and you're the only non-Indian in the place - you know you've stumbled onto something good.  The short review:  Bombay Saffron Bhuna Lamb: Spicy, Tender, Tasty.  Onion Kulcha (filled Naan): Fresh. Yum.

The waitress was wonderful and helpful.  We asked for spicy and it came spicy!!!
author: Joel B.

description:
this has got to be the most confused wanna-be Indian restaurant (reminds me of AB's poignant remark in "Cheeni Kum" movie).
I am surprised at the food taste especially since I read that the owner has a hotel management background.
Setting up an Indian (or any for that matter) restaurant can be a stressful job but when I looked at the decor and the prices on the menu, I really thought I was going to get some good food.

FAR from it.  the food was terrible.  I got onion rings on my pakora platter!  Thats as awkward as it can be.

the biryani was horrible.  they said its north-indian - which should be a "Lucknow" style.  but it was a confused dish with curry in it (hint: biriyani should never have curry in it).  And it was more of a hyderabadi style less lucknow style.

the chicken hariyali kabab was just some boring grilled pieces (read Costco frozen stuff) smeared in mint sauce.  what the heck were they thinking?????  and such steep price.

raita was good.

the portion size was miserly- but may be it was a good thing.

service was lousy.  waiters made me wait forever (not that they were super busy - they were busy chatting) - didnt care, didnt know the menu.  it was one uncomfortable environment.

the decor was nice.  location was nice.  not too far from Hyatt where I am staying
author: Jishnu N.

description:
Many things to like about New Delhi.  First and foremost may be proximity to my hotel while in town.  Maybe that seems subjective, but given the large number of Indian places around that area of town, including another I tried, the quality of this place really stood out.

I ate here alone on a Friday night.  I was seated a bit in the corner, which is understandable.  Staff were friendly but never overbearing, several people checking in on me throughout the meal.  

I had a few wine options, and chose a nice glass of white wine, not too fruity or sweet.  Choice of wine, in my experience, exceeded the sort of run of the mill Indian places.

I ordered my Indian Rut: malai kofta, rice, and garlic naan.  Everything was fresh and nicely flavored.  I find malai kofta ranges from buttery to spicy (yellow or red?), and this was on the buttery side (yellow).  I'm an orange girl, so this was a little mild for my taste.  But totally decent.  I'll just say I mopped the last bit out of the serving dish with my naan and leave it at that.

However, this could be because the portions were smaller than I'm used to.  This had only 2 koftas.  I've had two koftas before in this dish, but they were big.  These were small, and so perhaps because I didn't do an appetizer or share dishes with another person. I felt I would have appreciated a bit more in there.

Of course, spin this another way, and this is the first time I didn't roll out of an Indian place stuffed or toting leftovers.  You can decide whether this is an asset or detriment.  Jury is still out over here.

In the end, I would send you here over any other Indian place in this area.  And I'd send myself back in there, too.
author: Meghan B.

description: Not a great Indian place. Beautiful decor but the food isn't anything to write home about. Don't confuse this place with "Little Delhi" (a block away...).
author: S I.

description:
It's hard to believe that little doorway leads into such a cavernous space. I really like the decor (complete with Zakhir Hussein on the speakers).

We weren't totally starving so we ordered a bunch of appetizers and sides instead of any main plates. I liked everything, the wife liked most, but unfortunately most of it was too spicy for my 6 year old daughter, even though the waitress recommended a curry that's "great for kids" and to me tasted totally mild.

All and all, good stuff!
author: John S.

description: Its expensive for the portions you get, but a good place for Indian food. Its not your typical curry place because the seasonings they use isn't too bad compared to other locations.
author: Connie V.

description:
New Delhi is a home away from home. The entire staff and Executive Chef Ranjan Dey are friendly and welcoming. The food is fresh and my wife and I devoured our plates. A wonderful place for a cozy date night in downtown SF!

Recommend: The onion and garlic naan. Try their mango martini's too!
author: Pari M.

description:
I was actually a fan of New Delhi but I have to mark them down a star based on how we were treated last time.  We were late for our reservation, which I know is bad, but the power trippin' host made us sit and wait for almost 20 min. for a table while the restaurant was EMPTY!
Anyway, though our waitress was truly wonderful, the attitude of the host put a real damper on our big Valentine's Day dinner, and I don't think I'll go back again.
As a matter of fact after writing all this and remembering it again, I'm downgrading my original 3 stars to 2.  There are other Indian Places that are just as good and not so stuck up.
author: rhiannon g.

description:
Took the rather long stroll on Friday from my office to this preferred spot of my co-worker's, but it was a nice day out so the walk was nice.  It was also good knowing I would have this long walk back because I was about to feast on some good Indian food!

My buddy knows all the staff and half the customers in there because he's a long-time regular, and evidently many other folks are as well.  He explained that while many restaurants can be a mix of Indian and Pakistani, this one was purely Indian.  New Delhi boasts a very reasonble lunch menu ($6.50-$7.50) but since this was my first time there, my friend wanted me to order off the regular menu and also suggested we (4 of us) do family style.  OK by me!

So we ordered up the Lamb Vindaloo, Chicken Tikka Botti (skewers) and Bengan Bartha.  I should interject here that thanks to my Yelping (and need to document what I ordered), I will FINALLY get to know an Indian menu.  You see, all times previously I eat Indian food with people who order for me so I never learn.  Oh, we also ordered up some nan (of course!).

The Bengan Bartha was my favorite.  Absolutely delicious, slightly sweet...maybe the best Indian dish I've ever had.  The Lamb was also outstanding.  The Chicken skewers were good, but pretty average.   All in all, this was easily one of the best Indian meals I've had.  Service was solid.  Prices were good.  I can't wait to come back, perhaps bringing a few new people and spreading the good word.
author: John K.

description:
Well, let's start at the beginning.. You really *should* get a lychee martini. They infuse their own vodka! They're amazing!!!

The food is good every time I've been there so I'm not sure what all these bland reviews are! Maybe they got a new chef? Who knows. But I've been going there for a while and I've never experienced anything like that. As a matter of fact, their Vindaloo is probably my favorite. It's SUUUPER spicy!

All the standards are good as well. I've had better tandoori but there's is still on the very high side and the portions are generous.
author: Amy B.

description: I have to say...I was pretty disappointed with this place. I figure that one of the perks of living in SF is the abundance of great ethnic foods, so when I stumbled upon this place when I was in Union Square doing some shopping, I was super excited! The food was mediocre, the prices outrageous ($19.95 for Chicken Tikka Masala?!?!?), but the vibe was great. I really wanted to love this place, but I have certainly had better quality for less money. The serving sizes were small, but the waiter was really nice and eager to please. The somosas and naan were AMAZING though. That's where the 2 stars come in!!
author: Melanie M.

description:
Rather disappointed. If you're an indian looking for indian food - STAY AWAY. I can't stress this enough. An indian restaurant that makes tasteless pulao and seekh kabab that has an overabundance of cardamom (Seriously , cardamom ?!)

Decor and Service - ok. One of those Dark, high-ceiling places with pictures of people from a time long gone. The staff were friendly and prompt.
author: Wandering B.

description:
i want to love this place more then i do.
maybe because actual indian people were eating here. not just hipsters and yuppies like the rest of sf.
maybe because the atmosphere was funky and old school like some place you walk into by accident in chicago or nyc.

BUT, the food was only ok. nothing inspiring. just filling and forgettable. no upset stomach, no glowy, after consumption buzz. just not hungry anymore.

the only exception? the poppadom! i am a fan of these chips from heaven and this place has the best! they stole the show!

the waitstaff was friendly yet disorganized.

and the hood--yup--the hood. filthy pit of borderline tenderloin. step over the trash and be escorted in by crusty homeless people trying to get to the door knob before you to open it for us (?) but too waisted to make it in time--ug!

anyway...we ate, we drank indian beer, watched bollywood flicks on the screen with no sound, we moved on.
author: Bad Ass Chic K.

description:
The food is just 'regular' at best. You can get much better food at any mom & pop Indian restaurant. There is absolutely nothing great about the food. SERVINGS ARE TERRIBLY SMALL. Therefore we felt cheated.
The food might be 'ok' for AMERICANS who don't know any better. But for someone who know about Indian food, this restaurant and its food is just a DISASTER. So save your money and taste buds by going somewhere else.
author: Ajay T.

description:
Ordinarily I would give a place like this 3 stars, but it has the best papadum ever, which deserves a bump.:)  Seriously, I went back the next day just to get two orders of papadum, it was so perfect. Also, both the mango lassi and regular (sweet) lassi were great.

More generally speaking, I found the food to be so-so. It was definitely too spicy for my taste even though these were not items indicated as spicy.

The staff was friendly and helpful, both at the bar and in the restaurant. 

Given the proximity of this restaurant to nearby conference hotels, I'm surpsised it's not more packed. It is definitely a good option for a meal during a professional meeting and you can't beat the location for attendees.
author: Eszter H.

description:
TERRIBLE SERVICE. ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE. And I thought maybe I was just there on a bad night ... my friend had the same experience on her own, and I didn't even pre-bias her against the place. 

Food was above average, but I would never go back again.
author: Antara B.

description: My favorite indian restaurant in the city. The only reason they don't get 5 stars is, I thought the service could be a bit better (Ranjan wasn't there that night).
author: Mayur A.

description: I wandered into New Delhi last Monday evening, on what turned into The Giants' World Series win.  I was lured in by their delicious menu, full bar and luxe television.  I dined at the bar like one of the guys.  Unlike the guys, I ordered New Delhi's Indian inspired lemon drop with a sugar rim.  While I didn't taste anything out of the ordinary in my cocktail that might differentiate it from your stiff and standard lemon drop, my lemon drop and it's practically identical cousin still packed a potent punch.  I curbed my drunkenness with a lamb dish in yogurt sauce with rice.  Then The Giants won and the guys handed me a shot of Patron.  Is it possible to get crunk up in the Indian bar?
author: Camille K.

description: This place is a staple when I stay at the Parc 55 for work (or anywhere else in area).  Food is okay but I really go there for the bartender. :) nuff said.
author: Cristina W.

description: We went here for dinner and the food wasn't bad but the portions where small and it was expensive. There was two of us and the bill was $76 for three dishes and two appetizers. I had a regular ice tea  and my friend had a coke. We each got a refill and we where charged $12. No free refills I guess. This is about typical of what I have found at a few places in that area. Sub standard food that is over priced. It is a tourist trap that I think must rely on mostly one time tourist traffic. Don't bother with this place. Its not worth it.
author: Isaac S.

description: Decor is nice. Food is average. The food servings are extremely small for the price. I would not go here if very hungry!! Service is friendly........worth a try....but certainly on the pricier side.
author: Vikram P.

description: Worst experience ever in San Fransisco. Our waiter misbehaved with us and made us feel discriminated which was a bit too much. Food quantity was way much lesser than normal I would say  a hungry person would require 2 dishes along with bread to pacify his appetite. I am writing this review because I visited this restaurant after reading YELP review......
author: Ashish S.

description:
$32 lunch, friends. Yes, you heard that right. 

Actually, $37 with tip.

As Wyle E. Coyote would say: Yipe!

That said, the food was truly fantastic, and if not for the price and the feeling of being nickel-and-dimed (a tiny, bar-sized glass of iced tea - which costs them...um? nothing? for $3 which they didn't even refill) I would eat here a lot when in SF and give it 5 stars.

I usually see Indian food, at least in my neighborhood, as more of a reasonably-priced, savory option than something in the fine dining category. That, and more stuff is included in the price of the entree. 

I had ordered the chicken tikka masala (truly fabulous) with naan and some reita (sp? - you know, the yogurt sauce, which was the best I'd ever had) and rice.  The chicken alone was $18, plus $2 for rice (which is usually included) and $4 freaking fifty for the reita. WTF? $4.50 for a small bowl of yogurt sauce with cucumbers? Holy crap.

So if you want terrific food and money is no object, head on in, since your only disappointment will be the dent in your wallet.
author: Krys G.

description: I had New Delhi cater my wedding last week and I couldn't have been happier.  The chef, Ranjan, was courteous, professional, and readily available by phone or email for any questions or concerns I had.  The set up and break down the day of the wedding went seamlessly. The food was excellent. My guests raved about the buffet! If you choose indian food for a large event, I highly recommend New Delhi restaurant.
author: Jennifer B.

description: The vegetarian entres here taste like instant, boxed indian food. The panner was brown, not fresh and should be called poo-near.  The garlic nan had not one piece of garlic on it.  It was powdered garlic, or some saffron colored, tastless substance instead. This place is obviously catered to the tousists who may not know better or may think that's this is the best SF has to offer. If that's the case they should goto Maharani at Polk & Post Streets.  Now that's real indian food. Don't waste your time or money eating veggie fod at NDR. The ambience, however, is very nice; the service is good; and the house red & white wine is actually decent.
author: Geoffrey L.

description:
The restaurant is nice.  Very pretty ambiance.  The service generally was very friendly... one complaint is that they allow children and many families brought v. small kids with them... many who liked to scream and cry for attention which can be pretty distracting during a romantic dinner.

The food is actually decent.  My complete non vegetarian meal was pretty tasty and the chicken in the masala and tandoori tasted fresh.  I would recommend the tandoori- good flavor.  We never got our coffee/tea.  The dessert was pretty puny and there were no spices in it.  I also think the rice could have been a bit tastier.   

The main reason for 2 stars is that the prices are very exorbitant.  We had drinks at the bar waiting for a table (which was supposed to be 20 mins and ended up being closer to 40-45.)  Two cocktails and two beers at $25 plus tip = $30.  The cocktails are VERY STRONG and not well mixed.  I've had way better lychee martinis and the Oh Calcutta was very alcoholy tasting.  My Anchor Steam in a bottle was $6.  Sigh.

The meal was good, like I said, but definitely not worth $27 and $22 respectively.  My boyfriends complete vegetarian meal was a bit bland.  All in all with tip and drinks it came out to $100.  Hmmm... $100 is a bit too steep for the food.  I can go and splurge on a 4 course meal at Gary Danko for that price.  I think you can do better at Pakwan or Bombay or at the many great CHEAP Indian restaurants in the East Bay.
author: erin k.

description: Rahnjan and Sara are delightful to work with always smiling and just overall very generous people.  Their restaurant has been raved about by friends for months and finally, I got to see what the hype was all about.  New Delhi catered our last monthly meeting at the SF Golden Gate Club and they did a superb job.  I loved their saffron rice, their chicken and the veggie fritters, but I am looking forward to a visit to the restaurant itself to share the experience with my husband.  Thanks again to Rahnjan and Sara,  truly an elegant and fabulous experience.  I would highly recommend them to anyone!  And they host beautiful events at their restaurant as well.
author: Bahvee V.

description:
Ok first, my wife caught one of the waiters drink a glass of water and replace the glass with other "clean" glasses as though nothing happened. Garossssssss!!!!!

Second, a lady walked in with her stinky dog!!!! Yes, and sat on the table next to ours. The dog was quiet, but grossed us (and several others at other tables) out. We spoke to the manager/owner who told us that it was a service dog and the owner had diabetes or something.It was one of those furry kinds, hard to believe it was a service dog. But even more mind boggling was the dog owner downing martini after martini and chomping on tandoori chicken. Diabetes my ass. anyways, so one family was so offended that they left in 2 minutes and we complained. The owner of the restaurant was just comfortable letting more than 1/2 a dozen customers go over a dog...oh well. 

Wondering why I haven't commented on the food yet.... Hum ho... Yawn, I already told you the most interesting parts.
author: Linus L.

description: I had been hearing about how amazing this place is for a LONG time, and so when we FINALLY made our way in here last night, it was beyond a disappointment.  The young hostess who greeted us was amazingly sweet and personable but that's where the good experience ends.  We were stuck with the buffet, which was cold and lackluster.  The waitstaff didn't seem to motivated to help with anything, adding to the already awful taste in my mouth
author: d h.

description:
Stumbled upon this place after a day of shopping in union square.  Upon moving to SF three months ago, I made it my personal quest to find the best chicken biryani in the city.  Earlier this week, I succeeded at New Delhi.

The biryani was spicy, but well-mixed.  A perfect blend of flavors and textures.  Not too dry but not soupy.  Unfortunately, the dish was 19 dollars and on the smaller side (no leftovers), but I still know I'll fork over my hard-earned work-study salary on a bi-weekly basis.

Upon reading the reviews on yelp, I splurged and tried the garlic naan.  Definitely as good as they claim.  Doughy, but not soggy; zesty, but not full of garlic bits.  

This restaurant is a beautiful establishment.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
While the wait staff here won't hold your hand and warmly talk to you about Karmic Yoga like the good folks at Taste of the Himalayas, Ranjan Dey runs a pretty tight and friendly ship here in an ornate restaurant that makes you forget the troubles of the neighborhood outside.  

The staff are super friendly and devoted as lead by Ranjan.  Rumor has it, he's about to do a multi week special on PBS about Indian cooking.  Is that the new Martha I smell or is that just the curry?
author: Sean S.

description:
I've been craving good Indian food since I moved over here but have had a few disappointments. So when a friend recommended this place my hopes weren't high.

Oh my word. The food here is fantastic, just like home. The lamb rogan josh was superb, well spiced without inducing a sweat, the nan bread soft and sweet and the dal was heavenly. They even have bottles of Kingfisher!

The dishes themselves are quite mild but they are willing to spice them up to 'toilet paper in the freezer' standard if asked.

There's a small but cozy bar at the entrance and the décor is very nice. The staff are also very friendly. All in all a real find.
author: Iain T.

description:
I have no idea why a group of people who i was with chose this place, but one of the worst restaurant experiences ever. 

The food is not even close to being delicious, atmosphere depressing and service of 1-star.
author: Katja S.

description:
New Delhi is pretty good. 

Dim, incandescent lighting always a plus, calm ambiance, as in, keep conversations to a murmur. 

I wanted a little bit of this and that, so settled with the non-vegetarian dinner. Full dinner I should say. I enjoyed the aesthetic of food served in a thali.
