Main courses included some tandoori chicken, rogan josh, spiced vegetables, pullao, and naan. Servings were quite small, but plenty if you did not intend to gorge yourself to begin with. One of the tandoori pieces were a bit tough, but luckily the other was not. Rogan josh was very piquant with the smooth, strong blend of curry and spices, but was still able to detect the lamb, which was good. Naan was served fresh, and rice was fragrant. 
Completed with dessert of a trio of ice cream (pistachio, mango, and green tea), and cup of chai. 

Not bad!
author: Stef Y.

description:
This place looks and feels better than it really is. I was very disappointed in almost all kebab style meats that came out of the tandoor. I had a mixed grill as an apatiser and everything was dry as a bone and not the succulent meat you expect out of the tandoor, the chicken was bone dry and appeared to have been cooked and reheated. The only edible kebab style meat was the shish kebab and that's only because ground lamb is oily enough to be difficult to overcook. 

The curry style dishes were better, as were the vegetable dishes. I will try this place again just in case but my first experience was underwhelming especially when your expectations are set so high by the opulent surroundings.
author: Karl L.

description:
Sometimes I feel like it's a spot no one knows about. You'd never really notice it wandering around towards Union Square and Ellis certainly isn't a street you'd just go for a stroll on.

I've been here twice with about a group of 6 or more, and service has always been attentive and consistent. My last lunch here was my goodbye lunch as i was leaving my job. That being said, all bets were off and we were going to town with the menu! 

Very opulent yet reserved interior. High ceilings, large tables, a full bar and extensive menu. It's not Naan and Curry, so don't expect those prices. I'd say dishes start around $8-9 and go up to about $14 per plate, but if you're sharing, it's like getting a bit of heaven in everything. 

Perfect for groups of 2 or more, even up to 10, but single diners-I agree-may be a bit overwhelmed. Who really can eat an entire dish of palak paneer unto themselves anyway and not pay the price...

My favorites are the chana masala, the paneer tikka masala and saag gosht. Their pinot isn't that bad either!
author: Jessica P.

description: I ate dinner here a few months ago and thought it was pretty good, though a bit expensive. In particular, I loved their dal, which was wonderful. On the other hand, their chai tasted of oversteeped tea and too little spice.
author: Todd H.

description: Great service from the gentleman in the glasses. Another gentleman was impatient with my understanding of his English, but they make a mean madras. I initially confused it with Little Delhi which is around the corner, but was pleased anyway.
author: Matt K.

description:
Our nieces from Kentucky visited this weekend and had never experienced Indian food; and since Jessica (who is 17) is a pescetarian, we decided that Indian would be a great choice for our Saturday dinner.

So; around 6PM on Saturday, I logged into OpenTable.com and searched for Indian in SF. The New Delhi Restaurant had an opening for 4 at 8:30PM; so I booked it since we live nearby (The Brannan in South Beach), the on-line menu looked great, and their wine list is sufficient and reasonable.

Unfortunately; not having teenagers and not being around them much, I didn't anticipate how long it would take for them to get ready for dinner. By the time we were walking out the door; it was 8:15PM and we figured we'd just cab it instead of walking. Well; the cab we ordered was whisked away by someone else and we had no luck flagging one down, so we ended up walking the whole way. At 9:00PM; we arrived at the restaurant and our reservation had been canceled (which is to be expected).

The restaurant was packed and there was a waiting list on which we were 4th in line. We were told it would be about 30 minutes maximum which was fine with us as we were thrilled they could get us in at all. But; a few short minutes after we sat down at the bar table (no time to even order a wine (for us) or Coke (for the girls)), did the host grab us and take us to a freshly set up table (the one reserved for the "Advisor to New Delhi"). I only hope that the 3 two-tops in front of us weren't annoyed; but they were all seated shortly after we were.

The menu is expansive and fantastic; very artistic with historically significant descriptions. Our nieces were overwhelmed and while my husband and I knew what we liked; we weren't sure what to order for them since they're not fond of spicy food. But; to our VERY pleasant surprise, our waiter (Mohammed) was also the chef! We explained our situation; he made several recommendations and advised us on a couple of selections that we were considering. Bottom line; we had our whole dinner ordered with the greatest of ease.

Jim and I ordered and shared a green salad and dal soup; I have to admit, the soup was probably the best I've had. The girls had chicken tikka masala and the vegetarian version of the same (for Jessica) - both were very flavorful and mild (to our tastes), certainly the perfect choice for anyone new to Indian cuisine. Mohammed suggested the lamb vindaloo for Jim - it was perfectly spicy and fabulous, the sauce was perfect for dipping the wonderful assortment of naan bread that we ordered. Finally; we ordered the mixed Tandoori grill as well as a vegetarian version, I would order both again. In particular; whenever I've had fish made in the Tandoor oven in the past, it was always overcooked. The fish that came with the mixed grill was perfectly cooked (very tender and moist).

We ordered a red Zinfindel; at $24 a bottle, it was a bargain. As the girls were new to this kind of food and the inherent spice that accommodates it; the staff amazingly kept their water glasses full.

We will return!
author: Kymberli S.

description: I did not have the experiences of others here, and my bill was correct on two visits.  My malai kofta was alright, with the sauce being wonderful but only two large junks for the kofta balls.  Just two?  They redeemed themselves with the paratha here, which was among the best I've ever had (naan was just ok).  Duvel and other quality craft beers on tap were nice.  Better, cleaner, more upscale-ish atmosphere here too compared to other nearby options.  Prices were a notch too high as well.
author: Albert H.

description: I won a gift certificate for dinner at New Delhi at a wedding industry event and was excited come eat at Ranjan's place since it was highly recommended.  Ranjan greeted us and made us feel at home.  He asked our likes and dislikes and took away our menus' and brought us an amazing selection of food.  To top it off their signature drinks like the mango martini was delicious.  We finished off with some chai and a very tasty honey liqueur.  My friend Crystelle said it was in her top 5 meals she has ever had in SF.  Now my fridge has plenty of leftovers and i can't wait to go back and have other friends experience the food.  Thanks Ranjan!
author: Gustavo F.

description:
I was supposed to meet my friend at Little Delhi, but she made the mistake that I'm sure many other have, and ended up going here instead. She had already ordered a drink, and since it's just a block away, I just met her here instead.

At first, we thought it was going to be more expensive based on how it looked, but the prices aren't that bad, more expensive than most Indian places though. The service was pretty good, very friendly, at points almost too friendly. 

I have to say, I was expecting more from the food. Don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but based on the price, I just thought it would be fancier. I appreciated the fact that they have a full bar, I ordered the New Delhi Sunset, and it was very refreshing. As an appetizer I got Bari Pakoras, they were nice and crispy, and not too oily. For the entree, I got the chicken Korma and Garlic Naan. I usually get Chicken Tikka Massala, and wanted to try something a little different. I enjoyed the Korma, very delicately spiced and tender bits of chicken. The Garlic Naan was ok, not the best I've had. Overall, very tasty food, but not the best Indian I've ever had. 

I gave it four stars for the combination of food, service and atmosphere. The atmosphere is worth the extra $$.
author: Kelly L.

description:
I've walked by this place a thousand times, but it didn't exactly look like the kind of place that you just pop into for a quick bite. And it's not. But for a lovely evening out with a special someone, it's an excellent choice. It's a bit expensive for Indian Food, but not when you factor in the service and environment. It's quite lovely inside, and we were treated very, very well and everything we ordered was delicious.

We'll be back.
author: Dan W.

description: Samosas with buttery crust (assuming it was butter) which was a bit flaky and just melted in my mouth.   Great lamb saag.  Clean environment and courteous service.  Hit the spot when you're looking for Indian food after 9pm in the 'loin.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Dubbed "Smelly Delhi" by everyone I know, the bar section during happy hour isn't too shabby.  If it were up to the younger generation to determine our weekly destination, we would be at The Mint.  The New Delhi reminds me of an ex-pat pub, and when our bosses tag along, that's what I turns into!  

Happy hour is the only time to go, but you never know when it ends since one drink you order will be $3.50 (wtf with the 50 cents?  They are really trying to con you out of an extra tip, because who wants quarters in their pocket) and the next will be $5.
author: Amanda A.

description:
Yelp does not post my reviews for some reason.
New Delhi Indian Restaurant  - You still only get one star
author: Lejo J.

description: Food we were served was cold, poor customer service. Not worth my money or time.
author: Sona H.

description:
I'm giving this place 4 stars for the excellent food and service.  i couldn't believe how fast the food came to the table from the time we ordered.  my frequent dining companion and i (who hasn't been as frequent because of personal relationship issues) anyway...ate here last night.  

we ordered the chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, yellow dal and chai tea.  all were excellent.  my gf loved the cilantro chutney but she didn't like that we were charged $3 for a bowl of pickle.

my mom is a great cook so it's hard for me to rate indian restaurants.  but the food was damn good.
author: shehreen j.

description: Five diners, five happy customers. Although service was slow, the food was very good.Reasonable prices. Great location for tourists.
author: Joe M.

description:
We went to this restaurant with hopes of having good punjabi dishes.
We ordered tikka panner and malai kofta.

Malai kofta was so horrible. Then we thought might tikka might be good but again we were so dissatisfied. 
They made us wait for 40 mins to. Get the order . The paneer tikka was so spicy that our eyes got red . Horrible. 
We will never go to this restaurant again...
author: Delhi B.

description: I will never return to this restaurant again.  The food was uneven -- Chicken Tikka Masala excellent, but Butter Chicken so-so and potato naan bland.  Prices good but not necessarily "bargain eating" -- it was $38 for two with no drinks, one appetizer, and two entries + rice + naan, before tip. But the only reason we took ourselves down to the Tenderloin (bad neighborhood) was because of the positive reviews and the fact that we had a 1,000 point bonus OpenTable reservation.  Even though we arrived at 8:50pm for our reservation -- 10 minutes *early*, and asked the hostess 3 times to record our arrival in OpenTable so we would be credited, they recorded us as a no-show and my OpenTable account was dinged as delinquent *and* we didn't get our points for dining there. If you are going to lure customers to your restaurant by offering bonus dining points, you should honor your commitment.
author: Kris A.

description:
I haven't had Indian Food this good in India!  
The atmosphere is so Lux India and is a true representation of the classy part of India that not many think of, but is an widening sector of their social demographic.  Not only is the food outstanding but I feel like all my senseS are reached at New Delhi.  The only concern is the hours of operation are odd--check to make sure they are open before you go.
author: Cherie T.

description:
This is a great little place.  The food was quite flavorful, but could have been more spicy hot.  I'm sure if you request it, they would comply.  The customer service was excellent.  I'm not sure what the other people on here are complaining about.

I am giving only 4 stars because the portions were a little small for the price.
author: Fred I.

description: We started off with a lycheetini that was delightfully strong! I think that was the best part of the meal though. They DO have chicken tikka masala on the menu and my sister and I ordered it... it was fine. We had garlic naan (think garlic powder spread on naan) and cheese naan (think indian quesadilla - pretty plain). We also ordered the tandoori mixed grill - it had several styles of chicken, salmon, and shrimp.. all very exotic but noting too flavorful. We also ordered plain rice that was sort of yellowish in color. So this place is A-OK.... not really spectacular though. I like the rice, naan, and chicken tikka masala at naan n curry better and I pay WAY less there. Total came out to about $80 for two of us - I did use a $50 gift certificate from Bay Area Half Off ($12.50 for a $50 certificate) so it was decent.. but without the certificate, probably not worth it.
author: Kimberly S.

description:
I've always been a fan of Indian food. This one in particular holds a special place in my heart for many reasons. One of them being that it's authentic and of course there's a full service bar in front of the restaurant. Can I bring you a cosmo with your naan and sag panner?

Their sag panner is the best I've ever tasted. It's thick and creamy with chunks of firm cheese. Eat it with the garlic naan and oh my god you might just pass out. The sauce for the chicken masala is thick and nicely seasoned. I always take the masala sauce and eat it with the pullao (basmati) rice, this in itself can leave me satisfied. The hariyali tikka tandoori left a refreshing taste of mint and coriander mingling in my mouth. To fully experience an Indian dining feast I order mango lassi to wash it all down.

As you walk in you see the bar to your right along with countless pictures if celebrities, local heros and other "family" members hung prominently (there's one f President Clinton using the telephone). Huge shiny columns line both sides of the rooms and a draped "throne"  that sits in the corner (I was told they use to have belly or Indian dancing at night) and Indian music in the background.

I always see the owners walking around greeting patrons. On busy days I even see them seat and take orders. Dishes are roughly $12-19 but you always have left overs.
author: Lola L.

description:
My husband and I went to New Delhi for the first time a few nights ago to celebrate our 2nd anniversary. It had a nice atmosphere and smelled really awesome! We ordered the tandoori appetizer plate that had tandori shrimp and chicken tikka which was very tasty. Off to a good start! My husband ordered the tandoori chicken and I got the chicken masala. Both were exceptional! The flavors in the chicken masala were so incredible - coriander, ginger, and other spices blended so well together. The chicken was cooked perfectly too. 

The only reason I am not giving this review 5 stars is because the service could have been a little quicker. The waiter never came back to ask how our meal was and it took him quite some time to come back around to bring the check. 

Even though the service was a little lacking I would definitely come back here again. My husband isn't really the biggest fan of Indian food but he really liked the food here and was raving about it to friends the next day.
author: Tree P.

description:
My memory is fuzzy. I am almost sure that this is the place a bunch of friends and I went on a bar crawl night because one of us was friends with the bartender. We arrived around ten to an empty restaurant, no more Jaeger shots on Jaeger night but the guy behind the bar kept us happy and got us drunk dangerously fast. At one point we'd gather in the back of the restaurant and marvel about the concrete beams there.

Well, truth be told, I think it all boils down to mixing. One shouldn't really mix all kinds of beer, cocktails and shots. That's even what I'm telling people all the time. Oh well. The next highlight of that evening was us stopping at a nearby Jack in the Box, ordering some food I have no recollection of at all and standing nine feet away from the counter, wondering why the girl behind it would call out the number that was printed on my receipt over and over again.
author: Roland A.

description:
Middle-of-the-road Indian fare that doesn't "wow" you in any respect. Tandoori chicken was grilled just right and had enough zest to keep it interesting for the first couple of pieces; the lamb curry lacked spice and verve, quite bland. 

Rice and naan are awarded passable grades; can't say the same thing about the mango lassi, which was rich and creamy but ten degrees too warm.

The decor is odd and quite uninviting - there's this rather ugly and hideous overhead flat lighting, draining the life out of the room. The crimson walls and large ceiling help accentuate that this could have doubled, at least spatially, for one of the rooms at The Overlook Hotel in The Shining. When you're at a restaurant you don't want to be thinking about this.

Dinner for two people without alcohol or dessert runs you $55, and given the unremarkable nature of the food, you're probably better off walking an extra couple of blocks to Naan-N-Curry.
author: Joseph K.

description:
over prices, lunch for two was $50, wtf??, all we had was one order chicken tandori, 1 order rice, two order nan, one order of some vegatable dish that was one of thier specialities.  I think the waiter updsold us on the veg dish, I saw it coming and should have stopped him...  but $50 for lnch that is too much.

maybe this is why they have 1/2 cards forsale on bay area half off, that is all this lunch was worth, didn't have a 1/2 off card so ended up paying full price...

the other bad thing is there is no lunch special  where you can get  a plate with 3 or 4 items.  I would figure this would be wasy to do, all they would need to do is put some rice and salad on a plate along with a veg and or meat options, they could have 2-4 options made up for lunch to choose from.

too bad the place has potential, I say try Little Delhi on Eddy one block over behind the Parc 55 Hotel
author: Fredz R.

description:
Stopped by for some takeout on my way back from the gym and was pleasantly surprised.  I think the place used to a Denny's or something, because it sure doesn't look like an Indian place.  There's a painting of some Italian looking chef on the wall.  

The food took forever.  Probably because it was made from scratch.  Afterall, the menu "guarantees freshness.  But it was good. I had the spicy chicken vindaloo and the chikcen tikka kabab.  The kababs were a bit dried (had better), but overall not bad.

The only troubling thing was there was some notice about food inspections, and apparently they got deducted points for some infractions.  But I'm not sick 6 hours later, so should be ok....
author: Tinou B.

description: I had the pleasure of attending a baby shower this weekend that was catered by New Delhi. Ranjan did an amazing job putting the menu together. Everything was DELICIOUS!!! I highly recommend them!
author: Natasha T.

description:
Definitely scores on the food, being well-flavored north indian style, without being too expensive --- most entrees are under $10, and the veggie entrees are under $9! A friend got a the O'Calcutta cocktail, and approved of it. The Dal Ghosht (Lamb with Black Lentils) and the Navrathan Curry were quite authentic, and the hot sauce we asked specially for, very tasty.

Service isn't their strong point. We went in on a recent Monday and I had to pull my Hindi out to get someone to pay us attention, but I certainly commend them for damage control and PR. They had the sous chef out there serving us, and talking up the ladies in the party like they were queens of the Orient, plus he handed us free lychee martini shots, so all in all, I went away upping my initial 1 star to 4.

And the men's bathroom stinks, and that's NOT ok, so no 5 stars for you, New Delhi.
author: Sameer S.

description: New Delhi catered our baby shower. The food was fresh, tasty and flavorful. Spiced just right for a group with varied pallets. Service was fantastic and attentive. I would recommend them for any occasion!
author: Erik D.

description: Love the lamb kofti.  We come here more to hang out at the bar on Sat nights (Scott is a great bartender) but the few times that we did have dinner, it was absolutely delicious!  Be warned though, you order your dishes separately - as in, the entrees don't come with rice, naan or other sides.  You definitely have to order something in addition to your entree or you may be a little hungry.
author: Amy D.

description:
This place is one of my absolute favorite restaurants ever!

I love everything...about the only thing that is missing is a back rub with the service, no joke.

They have great food, prices, service, ambiance (the place is classy). I have been there three or four times and every time my experience has been consistently wonderful. 100% of the time...I love it every time.

Mohammed treated us like family. That guy is one of the best at what he does. Attentive, friendly, warm. He even remembered our names after only being there once! Such a good guy.

 If you go order the Madras Madness...mango puree and rum...yum! The lentils are amazingly good...as well as everything else we've had.
author: Omar C.

description: On Saturday, there was no special lunch menu, just the regular dinner menu at lunchtime. In some reviews and menu reproductions elsewhere it is claimed that this restaurant has a lunch buffet. It didn't have one on this Saturday. The food was quite tasty and the service was attentive, though the cost was nearly double what it would have been if the alleged buffet had existed.
author: Jonathan P.

description:
I will never eat this horrible indian food. 

some people make mistakes in one of their dishes.
but they master to ruin each and every thing i ordered.
either it is not cooked or you can smell that its very old!

their  adds on tv should be banned!!.
author: chess t.

description: We ordered the palak paneer, the vegetable pulao, and the channa masala (garbanzo beans). The garbanzo beans were a bit under cooked, but the paneer and pulao were decent. The naan was standard, and the raita was decent. I also got a mango lassi, which ended up being very sweet and extremely tasty (though the quantity left me craving for more)! I would give this place 4 stars if it wasn't for the undercooked garbanzo beans. Also, as some of the other reviewers pointed out the dishes are overpriced. I actually wanted to order a chicken biryani but didn't get it because it was a ridiculous $18. The additional cost seems unjustified, since the quality of the food, while decent isn't much above some of the other Indian restaurants I've eaten at SF. The service was very good though: friendly, quick, and frequent.
author: C P.

description:
Haven't had such a horrible food in a long long time. Waitresses could not care any less about you.
When i asked for little bit spices in my food and, they gave me "special indian hot sos". 
Never heard about it in my life, Never wanna see it again. I just wonder how this kind of places even survive.
author: Hash K.

description: This place doesn't understand entree portion sizes and my experience with the food was extremely mediocre. I have had much better Indian fare in the bay area. They can charge whatever they want to but they should at least serve the correct portion sizes... big disappointment.
author: Pri S.

description:
My parents were in town and staying at the Park 55 Hotel near Union Square. We were in the mood for Indian and decided to try New Delhi - right across the street from our hotel. I was with my rents and didn't mind the 20 minutes that passed waiting for someone to come to our table. We were cracking up and having a blast, overall great moods. When they did come we ordered cocktails (yes please) and some appetizers and main courses, all in one fell swoop. 

Here is where the jolt came. When my mom and I order cocktails, we orders cocktails, this means drinks STAT. This doesn't mean 45 minutes for them to mix some juice at the bar. We had to ask 3 different servers mulitple times to get our drinks. Seriously, give us our drinks, its been a long day and my mom is thirsty. My father orderd us a second round when the first ones plopped down for fear that we might never get another sip.

When the food came it was awesome!!! We thought all the dishes were delicious. Overall, great food but poor service. I probably wouldn't go back here with my friends for a party or anything but it was a great meal.
author: Katelyn B.

description:
I feel a quest for good India food coming on (read: my disclaimer that I'm not a connoisseur here.)

Still New Delhi goes get a nod for single handedly getting me to start eating lamb again (they have this incredible lamb sausage appetizer).  And I love their Tikka Masala.

I've always had good service and the interior is admittedly a bit much (there are actually columns in the dining room) but I am yet to find better Indian in the city.

Yet.
author: Jenny S.

description:
I decided to have my birthday dinner here this past Saturday night. I had changed my reservations multiple times prior to this, to which they had no problem accommodating me. 

Nine of us walked in, and was greeted right away by the owner.  We had our own little section separate from the rest of the restaurant.  It was not full of people, and the other patrons were pretty quiet. Nice setting, cute layout. 

It was my party's first time having Indian food. We were pretty stumped on what to order.. except me :) I knew I wanted Chicken Tikka Masala and Sag Paneer. But the waitress was amazing, and she asked our preferences and described some dishes, and suggested what she thought we would like. So we pretty much left it up to her to order for us :) 

It was a wise choice, and we were all pleasantly surprised. Our appetizers came, and we were just picking and nibbling on things we did not know. (We had the Assorted Vegetable Platter)  Then all of a sudden, ALL our food came out. I can't recall all the names, but we had Tandoori Mixed Grill, Sag Paneer, Chicken Tikka Masala, Lamb Vindaloo, Baigan Masala, Pullao, Nan, and Mango Lassi.. maybe more?

It was delicious. Amazingly delicious. A wonderful first experience of Indian food. The waitress was amazing! She was very friendly, and went the extra mile by going to get sodas at Walgreens because they were changing the syrup out of their Coke machine. 

I left to the bathroom, and came back to be surprised with Ice Cream with Rice Pudding and something that looked like a grape.. and Candles and a Happy Birthday song :) And after sharing dessert all around, the owner gave me a beautiful handmade spice rack . That is going above and beyond what I expected!

Everyone was extremely FULL and pleased with the dining experience. Now as for the bill.. haha, not so pleasant after all.
author: Coco C.

description:
If I could give this place 0 stars, I would!!

My girlfriend thought we should check it out. I looked at the website, the menu looked interesting and the chef has been featured on PBS, etc. Pricey for an Indian place, I thought, but hey, maybe it's because the quality of the food is great.

What a disappointment!! The food was an embarrassment to the Indian cuisine. *Nothing* we had was worthy of our time or the $60 check we got at the end. The chef, instead of flashing his ridiculous turban on PBS, should be spending his time in the kitchen where he belongs (although I question that, too). I even volunteered to take him to a few of my favorite Indian joints like Dosa or Vic's so that he could taste some real Indian food.

I love Indian. It's my favorite. This experience was truly a let down. We had to go to Vic's in Berkley the next day just to cover the bad taste. We were not disappointed!

My point: go to Dosa or Vic's if you want good food. Don't waste your time and money on this disaster of Indian cooking.
author: Max S.

description: This place is the real deal, just as good as I used to eat when I lived in London. The Tandori chicken was perfect. Just make sure you get there at least a half an hour before it closes or you may not get to eat. Last order has to go to the kitchen 20 minutes to closing. I will be returning next time to the city with family and friends.
author: C J.

description:
By far the most disgusting indian food i have had in the SF bay area... seriously folks the hole in the wall a.k.a "Naan and Curry" serves far better food than this place. 

I went there yesterday with 3 other friends to celebrate a friend's birthday. We ordered dal, chicken tikka masala, paneer dish and a plate of pakoras. 

1. The dal tasted like it was dished straight from a cooking experiment gone horribly wrong. We had to order onion rings, chillies and lemon to fix the damn thing - but still inedible.

2. The onions in the chicken tikka masala were raw and the curry had not been cooked properly. 

On top of that the service was rude and definitely not what you would expect at a place like this. 

In the end we got a bill for $98... since my friend did not want us to pay, he had already given his credit card at the front before we met him at the restaurant. The waiter only brought back a $98 credit card receipt and did not bring a printed itemized list. My friend did not mind and tipped the waiter...signed the receipt and proceeded to leave the restaurant. 

Out of curiosity we asked for the itemized bill, since we were a bit surprised to see how expensive the place was. For a party of 4 they included a gratuity of 18% (I have eaten at countless restaurants and the policy is normally 6+).... so technically we did not have to tip..smart asses!

To top it all off, the bill was not a printed bill but rather scribbled with pen on a note pad... i am sensing tax evasion here!!

But seriously, CRAPPY FOOD, CRAPPY SERVICE, NO SHAME IN THE OWNER TO APOLOGIZE FOR THE BAD FOOD AFTER US CONVEYING OUR DISPLEASURE WITH THE FOOD.... DOWN RIGHT CRAPPY!!!
author: Arnav S.

description:
I aboslutely loved this place. I didn't go there for the food but I went there just to chill out for some drinks. I originally went there with about 5 girls and 5 guys to have a couple drinks before we made our way over across the street to Infusion. The location is very nice and what made it even more appealing was the elaborate jukebox! I'm a big fan of the jukebox because as a DJ you get sick of listening to the same stuff over and over in the club. The jukebox is connected to an internet sever which allows you to choose from all types of different music! 

We had a ton of fun, the bartenders were all a lot of fun and great hosts. The drinks could have been a little bit stronger, which is why I didn't give them 5 stars, but aside from that, great atmosphere to just chill out and have a couple!
author: Ajay A.

description: Lovely atmosphere, great service but very small portions and terribly overpriced for what you receive.  I ordered the chef's table special which included 3 apps and 4 entrees.  The apps were brought out all together on a small plate no larger than a coffee saucer. Four small picces of food - that was all they gave me to eat which was supposed to be 3 appetizers. Then  the 4 entrees came out together and they were also  very small portions. They gave me a tiny bowl of rice to start and when I asked for more I received a larger bowl but was charge an extra 3.95 for it - on top of $38 for the meal. It was also the most expensive draft beer  that I had all week in SF $8.
author: Mike C.

description: Expensive and over rated, however, the service was nice. I had much higher expectations for the Indian food, based on past experiences at various other places.
author: Manny F.

description: My two girlfriends and I happened to walk past this restaurant and decided to give it a try, best decision ever!! The service was phenomenal and the food was to die for. I wish I lived closer so I could go back
author: Grecia A.

description:
By far the best Indian food I've ever had. Sadly, I don't see why others said the food was bland. Personally, I think it depends on the item you order.I love spicy and hot stuff, and I'm often the one who makes things too hot when making meals for friends and family. Also, the menu does indicate that you can order things in grades of heat. 
I went with a group of six people who all got slightly different things and we all shared a little taste of each others. 
I came close to giving it five stars, but I'd say that the rice was the most lacking although I smothered mine with curry dishes. I can also see why there are comments about the BBQ chicken. It was probably the least favorite of all the dishes among the six of us. 
Favorite of all was the Tandoori Lamb with pickling and spices and the Dol Gosht, which could have been spicier, but I didn't order it that way. 
Only real con was the portion sizes with the price being so high. Rice and Naan are not included in your orders of entrée dishes. Expect to pay $20-30 per person.
author: AKa H.

description:
Tourist Trap
I know this is subjective but this place doesn't offer value for money at all.  Don't dine here.
The parking validation advertised on their website gets you only $3 off the ridiculous parking fees ($12).  
The food is forgettable and they serve very small portions.
2 currys, 1 rice, 1 nan, 1 coke = $45 before tip.
beer = $8
The music is atrocious - Indian pop / charty nonsense.
The menu and decor flatter to deceive - sets you up then definitely does not deliver.
the staff were poorly turned out, slow, and needed to liven up - the looked like they just came from a funeral.
It gets 2 starts as the food was the right temperature, and my wife liked the nans.
Disappointing as it got decent reviews on yelp.
author: A H.

description:
If you like to taste the real flavor of Indian food, make sure you ask them to make it Spicy.... Then the fun begins.
The portions are big, the food is flavorful. Also they do not load it up with oil (unlike other Indian restaurants).
I had Chicken wrap at lunch, took the left over half home and enjoyed it at dinner. The appetizers are great, try those Onion Bhaji (Fritters) but make sure you have red and green chutneys with them.

The prices are very reasonable, even though it is right in the tourist haunts.
author: Yoddha Y.

description:
There are lots of reviews here, so I'll just throw my $.02 in.

- Menus: best and most complex format for a menu I've seen.  I liked it.
- Service: good.  Not overbearing.  Attentive.
- Meal: excellent.
  - Saag paneer: very tasty - but I'm a sucker for peas and cheese. 
  - Murg Akbari: good, good!  Sauce was nice.  
  - Raita: Excellent, with lots of cucumbers.
  - Nan: Excellent
  - Mango lassi: Excellent.
- Notes: make sure to order rice; it's not included.  Monday night is really, really slow.  
- Price: fairly expensive, but a reasonable value.
author: John T.

description: Went here before seeing a show at the Fringe Fest.  The place looks great and the service was good but the food was bland.  Bland is not something I associate with Indian food.  We had curry style dishes like Rogan Josh, Chicken Masala, etc and I can't recommend any of them.
author: Jason S.

description:
Stopped in here for a drink on the way home from work.  As the other reviewers have mentioned, it's quite an unexpectedly upscale sort of interior--not what you would expect from an Indian restaurant in the TL.  I sat at the bar and had a couple Buds while watching the ACC/Big Ten Challenge on the TV, and also had some of their free happy hour appetizers (decent chicken).  The bartender claimed the food is great, and that the place had been there for 30 years--can that be true?

I only walked through the dining room to visit the restrooms.  A handful of people were eating, surrounded by these massive columns, and large photos of old-school Indian rajas and nizams.  

Anyways, a comfortable atmosphere at the bar, but I can't comment on the food yet.  Will do so when I make it back for a meal.
author: Suman G.

description:
(Visited 07/19/08)
The food - super good. The service - terrible.

What I shared with my friend:
Garlic Nan, Vegetable Pullao - Saffron flavored rice cooked with seasonal vegetables, Eggplant, Onion rings. 

I have to give this a 3 star rating because of the bad service. The excuse the service was terrible was because we were a party of 10.  After an hour and half we finally received our food as we were all getting out of our seats to leave.  

Walking distance from the SF Hilton.
author: Stacey G.

description:
I ate here with my family... we were starving.

Most of us are vegetarians, and there was only ONE "complete dinner" that's vegetarian. But do not let this fool you! If you look at the entrees, most are vegetarian/vegan.  We ordered the navratan curry, soya joshua balls, sag paneer, lentil curry. All vegetarian and vegan(except the chunks of goat cheese in sag paneer). 

When the food arrived followed by our set of garlic, cheese, and buttered naan and vegetable rice, the quantity seemed a 'little' upsetting. Each in little bowls. When we started putting the food in our plate, it surprised us how much can fit in those small bowls!

Also, other miscellaneous tid-bits are: the fancy plates on each table when you walk in and sit down are beautiful. Made me upset that we don't actually use them, they take it away when our food comes. Another excellent part of my meal is the Mango Lassi. DELICIOUS!!!
-- this review written by Simon
author: Scott H.

description: Overpriced beyond belief. Food tasted like it was out of a can and was made poorly, no spices and was very bland. Paid around 60 bucks for two people with no drinks. Not sure who these people are that thought the food was 5 star quality. I feel bad for thier taste buds.
author: D. T.

description: Nope. I was not a happy girl this time. Seems to me they might have changed their chef cuz the food was nothing close to what I had eaten last time. The portions were skimpy,the pakoda looking kabab had us intrigued and the biryani looked and tasted like Kashmiri pilaf adding to the confusions abound. I wont be returning for sometime I reckon.
author: Natasha I.

description:
This is probably the worse dining experience I have ever had in SF!

The only reason I am giving it 2 stars is because the food wasn't terrible and the price was reasonable. The only thing I liked about this place was the moldings on the ceiling...the architecture was amazing!

We went here for dinner after seeing a show on Geary. The show was great...but the dinner here after wards so awful!! 

The service was SO slow. Our waiter really could not have cared less. I almost feel that maybe he quite his job half way through our meal...because after the food was finally served we never saw him again. He was also really rude...when we asked about recommendations he rolled his eyes and said that everything was the same! What?!  He seemed totally annoyed to be working there. 

From reading others reviews perhaps we just came on an off day with an off waiter. I still would not want to go back. Again, the food was not awful...just not anything special.
author: Mahlia R.

description:
Went here for Valentine's Day.  Here are the main points:
1) Made reservation through OpenTable, very convenient; seated promptly

2) The service was HORRIBLE.  We were there forever because no one would bring us the check, even after we asked two different people.  We saw our server ONE TIME (when he took the order...an ordeal that took two other employees before our server finally came over and brought us water and took our order)

3) The food was really good...very different from what we're used to at the Indian places we love. 

4) The drinks were really good; one in particular was really strong

5) The manager was apologetic about the poor service and a problem with the credit card machine and brought us a free round of drinks.

Bottom Line:  The place has a large enough menu that it may be worth checking out again, but the service was bad enough to make me wait until I am in the area...although even then, I'd probably just as quickly walk to Little Delhi or Naan and Curry.   2.5 stars
author: Christine G.

description:
The food is consistently AMAZING and is one of my very favorite restaurants in the city (that's saying a lot considering the number of good restaurants in SF).  Everyone I have ever brought here has loved it and they never disappoint.

If you start eating here, you may never want to go any place else for Tikka Masala, except maybe India.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
The wife and I were looking for a close to hotel Indian restaurant, after walking all over most of the morning, and had seen this across the street from the hotel. It had a nice old school decor, not too opulent, but homey.

We had the Spicy Madras Tamarind Chicken and the Spicy Vegetables, with the Onion Kulcha. This was served pretty promptly, and as stated elsewhere the portions were on the light side, but this was a relief as we had gotten too much food at the previous several restaurants we had gone to. The flavors were very robust, as if the dishes had been prepared with fresh spices. This was slightly confusing because they advertise a high end brand of canned boutique dried spices.

Have not tried the dinner service, only the lunch. Very enjoyable.
author: Sheldon G.

description: The food was great, though I think $14 dollars for the portion of curry I got was ridiculous.  Also, the service was kind of bunk.  Our waiter was a condescending jerk that questioned us at every step.  ("Are you sure you want that?", "Why don't you look at this?" etc.  It got so frustrating...).  Also, upon serving our table they conveniently forgot my dish.  I'm sure it was an accident but still, it was aggravating when they served everyone and I had to ask where my food was.
author: Clayton R.

description: I love New Delhi!  I've worked in the area for a couple years now and visiting for lunch is always a treat.  I recently brought 2 coworkes along and they could not stop raving about how good the food was and asking when we could go back again.  I"ve stopped in the bar in the evenings as well and had a nice glass of wine while waiting to get food to go for dinner.  I always order way too much because I just can not decide what I want ... but thats just fine since it means I have yummy leftovers to enjoy for the next day!!  Food is great, staff is super polite and the again...the food is ALWAYS GREAT!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description: In a touristy part of town, New Delhi exudes a but of tourist flair with its rustic 'Indian' styled interior.  Menu is a little Cheesecake Factory like in its girth (no ads though) and includes a multitude of options, most in the $12-16 range.  Service was quite good though, provided by the almost exclusively Indian staff.  Food was very tasty, portions were ample and of high quality ingredients.  A fine, more traditional alternative to the similarly priced Dosa.
author: Eric M.

description: I love San Francisco...but after a while find that many restaurants serve the same vegan curry, garlic fries with parmesan, avacado salsa + chips, etc. This place wowed me with their pickled lamb kebab. I have no idea what the dish was actually called, but it tasted utterly delightful and is unique. This is a white tablecloth restaurant in a spendy part of town, and the prices reflect this. Still...when you want a splurge go for the pickled lamb!
author: Cameron K.

description:
I was asked to find a good Indian restaurant within walking distance of our hotel in Union Square.  I read the mixed reviews from other posters, and thought to myself, "Well, it'll either be great, or it'll be terrible."

I'm glad we tried it.  It was great!  I had the lamb dal, which was very tasty.  I would have eaten it all, but I was already full from the pre-meal samosas and cocktails (yes, they have a bar).

I tried my boyfriend's lamb saag, which was also quite tasty.

I didn't get to try any of the chicken vindaloo, because the person who ordered that ate it all himself.

The service was polite, prompt and attentive.  I didn't pay particularly close attention to the service being given to the other patrons, but it appeared that everyone else seemed to be getting the same level of quality.
author: Karen P.

description:
Very, VERY, average.  Nothing exciting at all.  We went for New Years.  The service was atrocious.  They billed us $170 up front and then disappeared.  When I asked about our table, the host says "you have to pay $85/person."  I informed him we already paid and he said, "ok, we'll then we'll find you in a bit."  My experience- the service was mediocre; the food was average.  A very underwhelming place.
All things considered, you can definitely find a better Indian restaurant in the area.
author: Jason Z.

description: I had my wedding there and, while the food and atmosphere were good, I was so disappointed because the owner had an agreement that we could continue our party until 1:00 and he left, left one of his men in charge, and apparently told him to end the party at 11:00, just as the dance party was really getting going. I had thought the owner had more integrity than to cut short a once in a lifetime experience. I recommend that you do not have a wedding or event there.
author: Celeste H.

description:
We came as a party of five on a busy Saturday night. New Delhi is a more upscale indian restaurant and the atmosphere is more fine dining.  But we wore jeans and didn't feel out of place.
Most importantly, the food was incredibly tasty and delicious. Yum!  We ordered 4 entrees and passed to share so we were able to taste all the dishes. The entrees are large enough to be shared by two people, but if you want rice and veggie sides those are a la carte.  We had chicken, lamb and eggplant dishes -- and all were equally good. 

We all felt this was definitely some of the best Indian food we've had and will surely come back.  Make sure you order the Nan bread basket which traditional, onion and garlic Nan. Service was good.. after serving entrees, our server was busy with other tables so we didn't see much of her.  She was very personable and attentive most of our meal.  Check this place out!
author: Greg G.

description: Bad Service, Bad food, Portions too small and of bad quality. Both veg and non veg were equally bad. I cant believe that a restaurant at such a fantastic location can serve such bad indian food. Most people rated it good and my friend booked this place for dinner and we all hated it so i decided to write this review.
author: Chaitanya K.

description: worst restaurant ever been to and iam not just talking aboyt indian food,,,,,,horrible wait time horrible food horrible portions,,,,,,,,,had to wait soooooo long to get food spent 60 dollars for two and still left hungry hoping to find a hot dog stand still open ,,,,,,wow this place just reall reallly sucked
author: Joe B.

description:
Visited New Delhi on a whim on a Thursday night around 7:30 without a reservation. Though half of the restaurant was empty, we were given an exasperated look when we told the host we didn't have reservations, and told we'd have to wait 15 mins. No big deal, especially given the sea of humanity seething by outside. 

After ordering drinks at the bar, the bartender asked us if we were waiting on a table. After we said we were, she gave a confused look toward the empty HALF of the restaurant, and said "that's odd". Just as she looked to the host to ask what was up, we were shown to our seats.

From this point on, the service was stellar. The food was very good, but nothing stood out. The atmosphere of the main dining area is pleasing, with tall captial-topped columns in ranks amongst the tables, and black and white photos of yesteryear's Indian gentry. We all ate way too much, and enjoyed it throughout.

HOWEVER, two less-than-pleasing things stood out. The first was that our table, and at least three others around us had a direct view into the bussing station, where a box of 4-hour fogger was prominently displayed next to dishes and glassware. One of our group mentioned that the roach-killer was visible to patrons, and the staff moved it after an unconcerned shrug. VERY unappetizing. 

The second was that the bathroom, at least the mens', was rank with the odor of urine. Like at a park bathroom, or a concert. It was really bad. Hold your breath bad. Given that the place aspires to a high falutin' Indian dining experience, the bathroom condition was a significant detriment to that atmosphere.

Overall the place was enjoyable, but I'll try other places in the future.
author: E G.

description:
i got the generic chicken tikka masala.  okay, i am not indian, and i am not an expert in indian cuisine, so to me, this chicken tikka masala tasted like... chicken tikka masala.  not exceptionally different than any other 6.99$ chicken tikka masala i've had -- except that this chicken tikka masala cost $16 and was tiny.  so after getting a side of naan and rice from this place, i could have gotten five meals at a cheaper indian place.  
by no means am i saying this food is bad, it was tasty, but tasty like any other cheap indian place.
surprisingly,  this place is super nice inside.  the servers are okay except one of them looks like he hates his job and wants me and everyone else to die.
author: H. L.

description: I came here for lunch with a co-worker once and it was alright. The food was way overpriced but we did not want to go find another Indian place around the area so we stayed. Its a fancy-looking restaurant but the waiter made me feel kind of uncomfortable. I still had not decided what to order and I felt pressured to order whatever I saw first due to the impatient look on his face. He looked kind of mad actually. He was not welcoming or offered anything in particular like I've experienced in other restaurants. It felt more like he dreaded every minute there and he just wanted to bring us whatever we needed so he could go back and sit down by the bar. It was just a bad vibe and unpleasant experience. The food arrived and it was good, not that I am an expert in Indian food but I enjoyed it. If this restaurant had more customer-friendly waiters perhaps I would rate it 5 stars. For now, I think I'd rather look up other Indian restaurants beforehand and read the reviews as well.
author: Kathy Z.

description: Not just you typical Indian food, we were surprised to find. Many of the dishes are unusual and based on meals historical figures ate. It was all just fantastic gourmet food and great service. What a pleasant surprise.
author: Steve S.

description:
Fine for a meal, stay away for big events.  The restaurant fleeced us by adding extra rental charges and bar minimums at the last minute.  Plus we were charged more for the bar tab for our simple dinner than at our wedding the next day (where we had more people and where the drinks were more expensive).

If you really want to have an event there, consider getting every detail in writing in advance, and keep an eagle eye on the bar - or even provide guests tickets or some way to track actual consumption.  Otherwise you end up with little evidence to argue against the outrageous bill at the end of the night.
author: K B.

description: This restaurant had horrible management. We came in to enjoy appetizers and drinks and the waitress said we could sit anywhere so we sat down in the dining area and then the owner of the restaurant told us to go sit at the bar area since we were only ordering appetizers and the entire restaurant was practically empty.. The food was alright and a bit overpriced. The service sucked and they do not understand the concept of customer satisfaction.
author: sarah n.

description:
The ambience was very nice and the location is convenient. The service was friendly, though I think we were one of only two tables occupied at the time.

The food tasted good, but I found some things on the dry side. The servings were rather small for the high price.
author: Alex W.

description: Went to dinner after the theatre, and chose New Delhi.  We were among the first ones seated, so when the food took a while to arrive we joked that we must have beat the cooks.  The samosas were quite good- large and very fresh.  The food was tasty, but very small portions.  Considering the price, there should have been more than 1 scoop of food per serving (average price of an entree was $15.)  The wait staff was friendly, but lacking.  Considering that for 3 people, we paid about $90. for our meal (no alcohol, only 2 sodas at $3 each in 10 oz glass with lots of ice-no free refills) I expected more than diner-style service.  When we asked to  take home our leftovers, we were handed a plastic bag and container to "do it ourselves."  Classy. When the bill arrived, we had rice all  over the table, with no move to help clean it, and were never asked if we'd like dessert. Poorly managed, over-priced.  Really, they need to decide if they are going to be a high-end restaurant or not. Tenderloin service at Nob Hill prices.
author: Marsha K.

description:
It's getting hot in here!!!

While in San Franscico staying at the Hotel Nikko I noticed an Indian restaurant.  Since I wasn't in the mood to walk around to find a place to eat I went in. I love Indian cuisine and was in the mood for something hot and tasty. Because I was eating alone I was seated right away. I reviewed their menu and was pleased to see that it included some historical background on the dishes. I ordered the non- vegetarian plate which included tandoori chicken, seekh kebab, chicken masala, spiced vegetables, nan, dessert, coffee or tea. I figured if I order a dinner platter I would be able to try a sampling of everything that they have to offer. To this day I have found no place that can match their Chicken tandoori. On the menu it talks about their tandoor oven that was brought over from India. It also says to ask the waiter to escort you to the kitchen so you can see it so I did. You think I was going to leave without a peek? To my surprise they escorted me to their kitchen and I met the chef and his assistant. I have never seen an authentic tandoor oven. They had two of them and I was surprised how hot it gets. A tandoor oven is a cylindrical clay oven used in cooking and baking The chef demonstrated how to cook nan. He placed the nan on the wall of the oven and within a second it was cooked. He asked me to give it a try but I chickened-out. That oven is hot and I wasn't going to risk burning myself. Just placing my hand over it, I felt my skin melting. How they do that everyday is beyond me. It was a fun, informative and tasty meal but one warning: the first glass of tea is included in the dinner special but after that re-fills are charged by the glass which is not mentioned on their menu.
author: Tina M.

description: Came here for lunch with my wife. Not to busy. Waiter came & took order. Everything was going well had the appetizer main course comes and we tell the waiter that we did not order these dishes. He goes and checks with the kitchen. I here some yelling and screaming from the kitchen. Waiter comes out & admits they messed up and I asked if they could correct the mistake. He say " kitchen is closed" mind you its only 1:45 pm. The restaurant is supposed to open till 2.  So we ate what they brought out. Waiter comes back with our check and i was shocked he CHARGED us for the original order. There was no discount, didn't even ask us if we wanted dessert. I told the waiter I was very disappointed. We have gone to many restaurants and this was the worst service i have ever had. But I will say the food was ok.
author: J T.

description: Mediocre best sums up this place. Service was decent, food was ok, prices a bit steep, portions were small, decor very nice. I'd recommend Punjab Kebab a few blocks away for better food at lower prices, it has no ambiance but if you're more interested in the food, hands down a better choice. But that's just how I roll...
author: Trishan A.

description:
let's skip to the end of this tragic story, to the part where we are handed a $75 bill!! and that's just for 2 people!

"oh sh3t!!" exactly!


DOH!!!!!!!!
author: natassia s.

description: Excellent. So far the best indian restaurant I've been in the city. I like indian food a lot and most of the time I get dissappointed when I go to restaurants in the East Bay. This was a total indian experience with the ambiance, music and pictures of all the Rajahs and Marajahs. The food, the most important item of a restaurant, was just perfect. I enjoyed the taste of India and I'll go again. It's expensive, I guess... but It's worthy, believe me.
author: CacaoRock J.

description: Whenever I have dinner with my aunt, she chooses this place. The decor is lovely and the waiters are nice...when they're around that is. I liked the garlic naan, palek paneer and the mango lassi but the disappearing act by the waitstaff leaves a bitter taste in my mouth.
author: Nathalie L.

description: I agree with Shoba's review, once you step inside New Delhi it's an entirely different experience than just your typical North Indian restaurant. The space is somewhat ornate in atmosphere, or at least they've made a strong effort to recreate some sense of a Raj dynasty. The service and servers are really friendly, helpful, and the food itself is above average for your usual Indian cuisine. Again, agreeing with Shoba, the bar comes strangely alive on some weeknights, seems almost a separate entity compared to the relatively tranquil restaurant section - the surrounding Union Square outskirts and lack of other drinking establishments might be the reason for this, or perhaps we were there on an industry night. Either way, for some pretty decent and tasty Indian food in a nice sit-down environment, you can't go wrong with New Delhi.
author: Nish N.

description: Disguised as a mild-mannered Indian restaurant in Union Square, this place weirdly comes alive after 10 pm when all the industry crowd starts showing up.  The restaurant is large and on the nicer side-- white tablecloths, cloth napkins, etc.  Service was excellent-- the waiters were friendly, and  the manager came over to check up on how everything was and ended up chatting for 10 minutes. The food was good and the menu had all the usual suspects-- samosas, koormas, naans, etc.  The drinks were also good-- we sampled two specialty cocktails before our friendly manager sent over some lychee martinis on the house-- all very tasty, and a bargain at under $6 each. By the time we left, the bar area was pretty crowded and people seemed like they were having fun.  All in all, I had an unexpectedly enjoyable meal!
author: shoba d.

description:
I went to New Delhi for a goodbye party for someone I work with. She had been raving about how cool this place is and about how much fun she has had at the bar. When the 5 of us arrived on a Fri, we were greeted by the bartender. He was pretty friendly and made us some nice martini's. The way the bar is set up, it's kind of hard to have a group. We pushed some chairs together  by one of the small tables, but we were kind of in the way of people trying to get into the dinning room.
After about an hour, the male bartender left and a female bartender replaced  him. She was not nearly as friendly and in fact, I might say a bit rude. When I went up to the bar to order another round, she made a point to help other customers first. I had brought back to her all of the empty glass, so that she would not have to come and collect them. I waited patiently and eventually got another round. The next time I went to the bar, the same thing happen, except this time, someone at the bar pointed out that I was waiting to her. After this round I had had enough and told me friend I needed to go home. While the drinks and the setting were pretty cool, the bartender was anything but!
Don't think I will be coming back.
author: Lisa A.

description: I had lunch here with my Director. I ordered the mattar paneer medium spicy and plain Naan. The decor is like an old diner, but I wasn't expecting anything fancy. The service was friendly from the buss boys to the hostess to the waiter. They brought crispy papadams with 2 different sauces.  My boss ordered a butter chicken lunch special which he must have liked since he ate it in like 5 minutes. My mattar paneer was perfect, it actually was on the hot side but I loved it. There was just enough paneer cubes and the Naan was hot and fresh and brushed with ghee.  They brought plenty of napkins and were on top of refilling our waters. Personally I loved this place. Oh and there was a whole cardomon pod in my curry. The mistress of spices added a rounded fragrant flavor.
author: Amanda L.

description: This is the worst Indian restaurant I have been in Bay area. The service was sooooo slow and it took us ninety minutes to get our order even when the place was half empty. The food was so tasteless that it was shocking. The chef needs to take some lessons in Indian cooking. don't waste your money on this place.
author: Sonu K.

description: I wish I could give this place a better review, but they didn't give my the opportunity to with my experience.  My husband and I were seated near the back of the restaurant, studied our menus, made a decision and then waited....and waited....and waited.  We ended up leaving after about 10-15 minutes of waiting.  Maybe one day we will try again.
author: Rise G.

description: This is "Cheers" on Ellis st. Everyone knows everyone here! Once you step in here, they will know your name by the end of the night too. Great place to chill and lay low, mostly industry people..but that's the fun part! I tried the food several times, and its good, no doubt. The main attraction for me is the bar and its diverse crowd. Bartenders are SUPER cool and they always make sure your glass is never empty. WARNING- make sure you're not working the next day..they make some strong drinks, you can easily party hard there, and suffer with a mean hangover on the following day! Don't say I didn't warn you..
author: First C.

description: Stumbled in here last night with a group of gals b/c we forgot to make reservations anywhere and it had good availability.  The bar area was really loud.  It was hard to talk.  But once we were seated we had a good time.  The server was great - he made solid recommendations and engaged in friendly banter instead of rushing to his next table.  The food was surprisingly good.  The naan was charred and extra smoky.  It actually exceeded my expectations.  And the prices were reasonable for the nice sit-down atmospere.  We ordered 4 entrees, naan, rice and one appetizer got away paying $20 bucks a head (there was 5 of us).  We stuffed ourselves and left a lot of food on the table.  Good stuff.
author: sarah k.

description:
i wish i would have read some of the other 1- and 2-star warnings on here before I went.  seems like something sketchy is going on here, i'll explain why.  but first, there are two positives ... i really like the food (my husband likes it too).  We are both vegetarian and we found some good choices.  Perhaps they're listening to the complaints on here (i hope so!)... 2nd, there is one waiter at lunch time who is really nice.  he really tries and he seem like a genuinely good person.  

not sure if it is the owner, but you'll know the guy i'm talking about if you go ... he has a "holier than thou" air about him.  not fun to deal with.  he seems to be the only one to handle the money, which I think is strange.  suggestion: trust your employees.  both times we've gone for lunch, it has taken way too long to get the food, so we're rushed to try to pay the check.  please try to get the food to your customers in a reasonable amount of time.  We ordered off of the new lunch menu this time; this should have cut our wait time down because, i'm assuming, you don't choose your most time-consuming dishes for your lunch menu.  

the lettuce in the salad had some slime on it.  that's something you might want to take into consideration.  

another thing i wanted to mention is that the first time my husband and i had actually tried to come here (many months ago), the hours on the door showed that they were open for lunch, but when we walked in the door, someone came towards us quickly and told us they were closed.  something strange about this place. after reading all of the reviews, i'm actually pretty skeptical about their business ethics.  

one more suggestions for the guy who handles the money.  if you are trying to encourage people to use your new lunch menu, that's fine.  but if you have people who are asking for appetizers in addition to what they are ordering from the lunch menu, well ... you can even say no to that, i won't fault you too much... but **then**, don't let the people from one table over order appetizers.  that just makes the first customers who were refused the appetizers feel very strange indeed.  overall, you made us feel very uncomfortable.  this last time we went was the last time we'll ever go.
author: Cat F.

description: Wonderfully warm and inviting.  Right on the cusp of dirtville is this Indian treasure.  We were greeted by the owner as if we were old friends.  He seated us, recommended dishes on and off the menu, and took our order.  The Tikka Masala was chock full of white meat and beautifully wrapped in a sauce that I could have bathed in.  The naan was cut in perfect, crisp triangles; just the right size for dipping.  We rounded off our lamb BBQ with two bottles of Taj Mahal beer.  An unexpected surprise!  I'd definitely go back.
author: Paul D.

description: I went there for dinner Monday night with my two sons and I have to say it is probably the best Indian Food I have had in years.  The Tandori is fabulous; the samos' are crispy/tasty and the Masala was out of this world.  My son is still talking about it; he had the Prawn Masala; not to mention their Mango Lasso - which were a big hit.  They also as others mentioned have the best Lychee Martini in town. I'm not a Martini drinker but this one was phenomenal & they do infuse themselves the owner told me. He is a very nice gentleman and there in person to oversee operations.  The decor was very nice too.  We had a truly enjoyable experience & completely forgot we were downtown San Francisco. I can only recommend this place!
author: Beth P.

description: Read a number of reviews on this restarurant and many were not good.  I was in San Francisco this weekend with a friend that lives in Hawaii.  We were in the mood for Indian food, so we found New Delhi on Open Table.  Many of the reviews said the service was terrible and the food wasn't very good.  To our surprise the bad reviews were completely wrong.  I loved the food and the service was great.  She felt the same.  I would highly recommend New Delhi Indian Restaurant.
author: Lamar H.

description: The best Indian food west of New Delhi.  Not that I have been to the city of New Delhi.  I just really like New Delhi restaurant.
author: Em P.

description:
I find it hard to judge a restaurant when I am starving and so was one of my managers...
So we really loved the food (chicken masala and chicken korma).... Im still a little limited on my choices of food .. I seem to order the same things all the time
The Naan was delicious...
Service was a little slow... I never liked it when the waiters do not want to take my money... maybe I should have ordered more than water and a Sprite to drink...
Also, we got put in the very back of the restaurant (since we didn't have a reservation).... I recommend calling before you walk in... maybe they will sit you with everyone else and not feel like an "alien"...
Or I have another idea... just walk in and say "Mariano...party of 2" and when they say "sorry, no reservation" ... say "what the hell is this?" and throw a big tantrum... Then they may sit you next to the bathroom...
You never heard this from me...
enough said...
author: Florio M.

description: It won't be the same without you... Mohammed, you were a dear friend. You're so loved because you were a wonderful man.  Until we meet again ...  R.I.P.
author: michelle r.

description: I haven't really experienced much here except for their happy hour specials which are awesome. Bartender there was really, really cool. Chatted with him for a bit and he was the type of bartender that really makes you feel welcome and want to come back, now that I think about it I feel kinda bad that I haven't been there for awhile. I tried the food once but I had a pretty good midday buzz going so I don't remember it so well. Definitely worth checking out for good drinks and good people.
author: Tommy P.

description: Love this place... one of the best Chicken Tika Masala I've had!
author: nancy v.

description: Had dinner at New Delhi Indian restaurant with my husband this evening and we really enjoyed it. We had samosas to start, which were supposed to be 2, but ended up being 4 miniature ones.  For our main we had Chicken Masala, Chicken Tikka, and a potato dish that was very good, similar to a korma. We don't usually order rice at Indian restaurants since we like to mop up the sauces with naan - theirs was ok..a bit doughy.  Service was fine, but a little slow.  Overall was a good experience, give it a try!
author: Tania J.

description: I went to a fundraiser that was held here because my dad is friends with the owner, so I didn't have an actual dine-in experience. But the food, was, amazing. I'm half Indian, so I tend to be unbelievably picky about where I go to eat Indian food (Mostly at home from my mom/gramma because it just doesn't get any better than home made). This food was fantastic. I'm not big on daal but MAN, so good. The tandoori chicken, the curry chicken, the galobjan (dessert, I think I spelled it right?), all of it was wonderful. I'd definitely go again. The owner was a really nice guy as well.
author: Rosie H.

description: I have been here a half dozen times or so and have been pretty impressed every time.   I can't give the 5th star since i am no expert on Indian food.  The specialty drinks are great with friendly bartender.  Every time, i have just had the waiter bring out a few dishes (depending on how many people i am with at the time).  Ranjan himself has even come by to say hi when things were relatively slow for a late lunch.  If you are looking for a place to get some good food in the TL, hit it up.  The only downside would be the price, but i suppose you get what you pay for.
author: Robert R.

description: yummy and had great lunch-special deals (2 veggie curries with rice, salad and naan for 5.99!) at first when we walked in i was a little worried cuz it was pretty empty. but by the time we paid and left there was a line out the door. service got kind of laggy.
author: abby l.

description: Stopped here by chance one lunchtime looking for a curry fix.  As other reviews have said the space is great, very atmospheric.  The food was fantastic but a touch overpriced.
author: JBO ..

description:
Staying at the Hilton on OFarrell, was surprised to learn there was an Indian restaurant just back door! Was very hungry when i arrived at the restaurant. I was promptly seated, orders taken. The guy waiter was the good one, the ladies were full of attitude. 2 Stars for the Service

The Vegetable Shorba is supposed to  be a light vegetable soup garnished with spices, but turned out to be a thick gravy dish which should be eaten with Indian Bread (Naan, Roti etc). Hmmm..surprised. On inquiry the waiter said "we always serve it this way!!" WOW but being from India i know what Shorba is and the way they prepared it. This wasnt the real thing. I ordered a Roti (Wheat Bread) which was good (this is so simple to prepare that it is difficult to screw it up!) and a Navarathan Curry (Gravy dish with vegetables and fruits). Surprisingly the Navarathan Curry tasted the same as the Shorba! That is ridiculous. Except for the tinge of sweetness in the curry, it was the same as the Shorba. I guess they had some readymade set of dishes which they serve under different names. I ordered a Salted Lassi (supposed to be thick yoghurt) it turned out to be very watery like buttermilk. I decided to try one more dish before passing the judgment. The Vegetable Biryani tasted like Sambar Rice. For comparison, it is like ordering calzone and getting a pizza instead!! The food is definitely tasty and eatable, but not authentic Indian fare. For those who dont know what Indian food is, it would not be a disappointment. I give 2 stars for food. 

Ambiance was that of a palace (though a cheap one). Carved high ceilings, ornamented columns, antique exhibits, portraits of different Maharajas etc. I like the inverted ceiling fans which were standing on pedestrals!! They were playing some fast beat hindi movie songs, would have preferred soothing indian classical music instead. The whole place looked little dull, could have done better with brighter colors and bettter lighting. I give a 2 stars
author: Sankar B.

description:
I am an experienced restaurant-goer and very experienced Indian restaurant-goer. Based on the enthusiastic reviews, I wanted to give this place a try. Now I regret it.

Poor service:

New Delhi took 15 minutes to take our first order, and did so only after we flagged down the busser. Dinner was very below average, and once the food was eventually served, we didn't see the waiter again. No more water. No more beverages. No more service. To escape, we had to flag someone down again to ask for the bill. And then, of course, no one would pick it up. So, I had to take the payment to the guy at the front.

Below average food:

Kofta were poor (no nuts, over-sweet sauce, luke-warm, tasted microwaved). Beer was luke-warm. Bhaji were stale-tasting. Sauces were over seasoned. Naan was actually not too bad.

Overall take:

This is a restaurant for tourists who don't know Indian food. A flashy menu and good decor don't make a good restaurant. But, they are trying to fool you.
author: Paul W.

description:
Five stars, hands down.  No question in my mind.

I'm not too familiar with Indian cuisine in general, but am familiar enough to know when I am getting quality Indian food rather than just moosh.  And this my friends is beyond quality in my opinion ...it was phenomenal!

Some coworkers and I decided to get together at this location as the restaurant had excellent reviews, and we were looking for good Indian food in the city. The menu online was quite extensive and exciting, offering dishes cooked in ovens transported here all the way from India!  Wow!  My partner and I arrived early and decided to have a cocktail while we were waiting (the restaurant has a beautiful bar when you first walk in).  The bartender was very cute and personable (always a plus...it should be a requirement in my opinion in this profession).  She not only made a mean Cosmopolitan, but she was friendly and helpful (and she gave us some personal recommendations from the menu).  So needless to say, things started out well.  Well enough where we thought we may come and visit her just for a drink when she is working.  In fact, she deserves her own positive review on YELP!  (All I know is that she works Mondays only).

Once our party arrived, we were promptly seated and ordered an array of yummy sounding dishes.  The food came out quick and was piping hot (always great).  I was blown away by the amazing spices and flavors,  and ate until I was stuffed (another good sign).  Personal favorites included the Prawn Masala, Onion Nan, Dam Alu New Delhi (Curried Potatoes), Samosas with sweet sauce, and Tandoori Chicken.  Just thinking about it makes my mouth water.

A little pricy but well worth it and you WON'T be disappointed.
author: Ryan H.

description:
very good food, good service and it has great decor.
if you are lost on Ellis st, they this is the place to find.
author: adam m.

description:
the naan is so hot and soft and wonderful, why don't i have more sauces to dip in?

the portions were a little small for my fatty american family, but the price was nice and so was the waitress. and we were annoying. we always have to try everything, so decisions become tiresome. and we drink.

the appetizers were lacking and tiny, the fish goa curry was wonderful if only for the curry itself. and the trio of ice creams the lovely lady brought us to end really made me smile.
author: shaine h.

description: Unimaginative menu, too-small portions, mediocre food, the rice & naan are dry, and the service is slower than molasses in January.  Bleck.
author: Asteridae A.

description: Best Indian food ever! Took friends of mine there who never tried Indian food and they are now fans thanks to New Delhi! A true extraordinary culinary experience.  First class customer service!
author: CorporateMom L.

description: We've seen their commercial on the weekends during Namaste America & Showbiz India. We decided to give them a try yesterday. The place was pretty empty when we walked in (and also when we walked out). We went to wash up first and I was mortified that they didn't have toilet seat covers in the bathroom!! Really? We are in the U.S. for God sake!! I ordered a cocktail that had cranberry juice, some other juices, vodka, & rum....it wasn't good at all. Tasted like a basic cranberry & vodka. We ordered chole, paneer tikka masala, chicken tikka masala, & their spinach kofta curry. The food took a while to come out & when it did, we noticed the portions were pretty small. Unfortunately none of it was good, the meat-eaters at the table said the chicken was "ok." The spinach kofta curry had close to no spinach in it & seemed to be served in a squash-type vessel....yuck. I ordered the paneer spicy & it was very bland. In fact, we had to ask for a salt shaker! Indian food is typically salty as it is, so you know something's off if someone requests salt. Because it was slow, the busboys were just standing around chatting w/each other, but were attentive when we asked for more water. Although, if it's slow, shouldn't they notice empty water glasses? Suffice to say, we won't be back.
author: L P.

description:
Went there once, won't go back. Food is over-priced, probably because of location. Dishes we ordered, were blend, even though we asked for spicy, quantity was small, appetizer (samosa) tasted like they just heated it in mircowave, some naans were overcooked some were undercooked.
